characters: ON THE WAY TO THE FOYER
RESUME THE AGENT AND THE GIRL
RESUME BARTHA, MRS. BARTHA AND SIDNEY
THE SENATOR, THE GIRL, AND THE AGENT
RESUME BARTHA, SIDNEY AND MRS. BARTHA
THE SENATOR, THE AGENT AND THE GIRL
BEAT HIS WAY BACK INTO THE COLUMN
THE AGENT, THE GIRL AND THE SENATOR
RESUME THE AGENT, THE GIRL AND THE SENATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A row of newspaper delivery trucks is lined up against th long loading bay, waiting for the edition.  In the foregr a large clock establishes the time as 8:10 PM. A rumbling noise warns the men to take their positions; a few second later the bales of newspapers come sliding the spiral chu onto the moving belts from which they are manhandled onto the trucks.  Much noise and shouting. The front truck moves out to the city street.  As it does CAMERA EMPHASIZES the big poster on its side.  The design features a large pair of spectacles with heavy rims - a trademark of Hunsecker's. (It will later be seen as the masthead of the gossip column.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "They eyes of Broadway"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck starts on its journey along Broadway.  Some sho are of the vehicle moving through very heavy traffic (tak from a camera car).  Others are from the inside of the truck; as it slows down, the delivery man tosses the heav bundle of papers onto the sidewalk.  CAMERA following the truck, holds it in foreground against the blazing electri signs of Broadway and Times Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The southeast corner of the intersection of Broadway and 46th Street, CAMERA, fairly high, shoots north towards th impressive vista of electric signs, silhouetted against t darkening sky.  Very heavy traffic and crowded sidewalks. CAMERA descends towards the Orange Juice stand on the corner, passing the booth which sells souvenir hats.  It moves through the congestion of chattering passersby, steadily approaching a smartly dressed young man, who sta at the counter of the Orange Juice stand.  Oblivious of t hub-bub around him, SIDNEY FALCO is concerned only with h private problems. He turns sharply as a newspaper truck pulls up at the cur behind him; this is what he has been waiting for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news truck delivery man tosses a bundle out onto the sidewalk besides a newsstand.

dialogues.speaker: DETAIL
dialogues.text: The bundle of newspapers.  It hits the sidewalk with a sm CAMERA PULLS BACK as Sidney Falco crosses the sidewalk. owner of the newsstand, IGGY, comes to pick up the bundle he is a grizzled gnome with a philosophical sense of humo Sidney snaps his fingers with impatience.  Iggy wears spectacles and is clearly more or less blind, he has to grope for the cord that binds the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw Lady, if I looked like you, I'd--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon...C'mon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognizing Sidney's voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep ya sweatshirt on, Sidney. Majestically taking his time, Iggy lifts the bundle to hi stand and cuts the cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Fresh, the Globe just came in -- Hey, Sidney, want an item for Hunsecker's column?  Two rolls get fresh with a baker!  Hey, hot, hot, hot -- etc. Annoyed, Sidney throws him a dime, seizes a paper and returns briskly to the orange juice stand.

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE JUICE STAND
dialogues.text: Sidney's place at the crowded counter has been taken by newcomers.  Rudely, he recovers his half-consumed glass o orange juice and sandwich.  He takes them further down th counter to a quieter corner at which he can examine the paper.  CAMERA MOVING WITH HIM, picks up further snatches overheard dialogue. (See dialogue attached at the end of scene) We move close enough to see Sidney's hands open th paper expertly at HUNSECKER'S column - identifiable by th picture of the spectacled eyes.  Over scene there is a babble of offstage dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is sullen as his eyes run rapidly down the colum He is reacting to a not unexpected disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTS WEST on 46th Street, as Sidney comes down t side street from the newsstand in background.  Irritably, jerks open the door of a shabby entrance.  As the glass d closes, Sidney is seen striding up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST FLOOR
dialogues.text: Beside the top of the stairs is the door to Sidney's offi On it there is a cheaply printed cardboard sign which rea

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY FALCO
dialogues.text: Publicity From inside comes the sound of desultory typing.  Sidney comes up the stairs two at a time and turns into the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLY is on the phone as Sidney strides in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Mr. Weldon.  I think... Sidney vigorously indicates that he doesn't want to take call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I thought that was Mr. Falco returning.  Yes, I'll tell him when he comes in.  I know he's been trying to reach you. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the third time he's called today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants me to break a leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (literally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, an arm, he said. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him you were sure the item would be in Mr. Hunsecker's column in tomorrow's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't.  I've just seen the early edition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes five days in a row that Mr. Hunsecker's cut you out of his column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I rent you out as an adding machine. He has begun to change his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me Joe Robard. Sally goes back into the outer room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else phoned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The renting agent and the tailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay the rent.  Let the tailor wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't leave much of a balance in the bank... (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Robard?  Could you locate him? Sidney, in a state of semi-undress, comes to take the pho from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gloomily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch me run a fifty yard dash with my legs cut off! Very abruptly, he comes alive on the phone.  A real laugh boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (effusively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, Joe.  How do you like it? I'm running out of alibis!  No, I asked Hunsecker to withhold the item, until he could give it a fine, fat paragraph.  The column was running over and I didn't want you kissed off with just a line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robard is a stolid, secure man, balding and with a mousta He has a morose sense of humor.  He is speaking from a telephone on a little desk at the end of the bar.  In background, the Club is open, but there are few customers yet.  Some recorded jazz is being played while the musici are still arriving, strolling past in background, deposit their overcoats and music cases in the little closet assi to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in answer to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. (he listens to protest from Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Sidney, a kissing game?  You're a liar - that's a publicity man's nature.  I wouldn't hire you if you wasn't a liar.  I pay you a C-and-a-half a week wherein you plant big lies about me and the Club all over the map. (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean in that sense.  But also in the sense that you are a personal liar, too, because you don't do the work I pay you for. (new protests on the other end of the line)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, stop it, Sidney.  You're from the country, not me.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sally is watching him, unhappy on his behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute, Joe.  When I saw J.J. last night he said... But Robard has cut off.  Sidney hangs up.  A silence.  Sa tries to be comforting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could help in some way, Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me with two minutes of silence! Sally, hurt, says nothing.  Presently, he adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, Sally.  It's late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to see you like this -- Sidney, with another mercurial change of manner, begins s sarcastic clowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horsing around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but as a new subscriber you're under no obligation to take more than three books.  And if you mail the enclosed card within ten days --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleadingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, I know you by now.  Don't do a dance with me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still clowning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you don't want the extra free gift of a colorful giant map of the world???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, please, dear, if you feel nervous... Sidney is abruptly savage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with cruelty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what'll you do if I feel nervous? You'll open your meaty, sympathetic arms...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid...you got me so...I don't know what... She is crying.  Sidney feels uncomfortable.  Not too generously, he relents:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to be used to me by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pathetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm used to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a touch of bitterness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You think I'm a hero.  I'm no hero.  I'm nice to people where it pays me to be.  I gotta do it too much on the outside, so don't expect me to kow-tow in my own office.  I'm in a bind right now with Hunsecker so -- (grimly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every dog has his day! (going)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock up and leave the key. The phone rings.  Sidney is dressed by now.  As Sally goe for it, he makes for the outer door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's for me, tear it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a top coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And leave a tip in every hat-check room in town? He is already gone as she picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney Falco office... Oh, Miss Kay, he tried to reach you.  No, he's at the barbers now.  No, that's held over till the Tuesday column...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quintet.  As the dissolve clears, a clatter of polite applause greets the end of a previous number.  CAMERA is the bandstand, moving smoothly through the group of five musicians as the rhythm of a new number is set up: first leader (a guitarist) snaps his fingers, giving the tempo to...the bass, who "walks" with the beat, bringing in...t drums, which start a quiet, insistent wire-brush backgrou for...the cello and the flute, whose introductory phrases set the stage for...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE DALLAS
dialogues.text: ...the guitar, the leader again.  It comes in after this short preamble with the first statement of melody. (The t has a faint echo of significance because it is one of the themes of the film, already heard as a phrase in the background score of the title music.) CAMERA lingers a moment on the guitarist, STEVE DALLAS.  He is a youth of pleasant, intelligent appearance.  He plays with the inte air of the contemporary jazz musician who takes his work very seriously indeed and affects a much greater interest the music and his fellow musicians than in the listening audience.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A close shot.  Sidney has just entered the club, strollin into the vestibule near the entrance.  He wears an expres of oddly unsuitable antagonism, as he looks forward...

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: Seen in long shot from Sidney's viewpoint.  CAMERA moves include Sidney in foreground again.  He turns as he is accosted by RITA, the cigarette girl of the club.  She is pert creature, attractive and not unaware of the fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you ever get messages, Eyelashes?  I called you twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been up to here.  Listen, honey, tell me something.  You know Susan Hunsecker...? (Rita nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has she been in?  I mean lately, in the last coupla days...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure.  Find out for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, can I talk to you a minute? Rita wears an injured air.  Sidney, preoccupied with othe worries, callously ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Frank D'Angelo around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bar - Sidney... But Sidney has moved away from her.

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: He is at the bar, listening with satisfaction to the musi watching the performers and studying the audience.  Sidne comes up behind him.  We see Sidney's eyes flick from D'Angelo towards the bandstand and back again.  Then, as takes the stool next to D'Angelo, he assumes a different manner, a sulky resentment.  D'Angelo sees Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, give my nephew a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your nephew doesn't want a drink. D'Angelo is still watching the quintet.  The guitar can b heard again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting past D'Angelo and Sidney towards the bandstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lollipop that, boy.  The kid is only great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with ten percent of his future, you're great, too, Frank. D'Angelo looks quickly at Sidney, sensing the undercurren Then he turns his back on the musicians, remarking in a quiet tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went over to Philly yesterday an' seen the folks...it's nice you send them the fifty a month...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See my mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only had a few hours. A glum moment.  Frank sips his highball: Sidney lights a cigarette, animosity on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the publicity spread you got the boys for the benefit tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (begrudgingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robard's my client.  I did it for him and his club, not your boys. Frank again notes Sidney's resentful manner.  Sidney look towards the musicians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, I think maybe you lied to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looka, Sidney, you're my own sister's son, but where does that give you the right to call me a liar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking towards Steve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me that your boy was washed up with Susie Hunsecker, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and it's the truth, to the best of my knowledge.  And, frankly, I'm glad.  For Steve's sake, I'm glad, not yours.  I manage these boys and I got their best interests at heart.  Steve shouldn't get mixed up with no bimbo at his age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (narrowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told him that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in those exact words - you know what a temper he's got. A pause.  Sidney is thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do these hot-headed boys of yours go on the road?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coupla weeks.  For eight weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a nice tour.  All booked? (Frank nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was Susie around here last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four five nights ago.  That's how I know the romance is off.  Also Steve's in a very bad mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Frank, you'd better make sure you're telling me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like this threatening attitude.  When it comes to it, what the heck is it your business what they do, this boy and girl...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Locating Sidney, she comes up behind him.  He turns away from D'Angelo as she whispers to him.  As she departs, Sidney turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you knew Hunsecker as well as I did, you might understand why it's my business.  Maybe you're walking around blind, Frank, without a cane. Sidney gets off his stool.  Casually, but to effect, he a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and in case you didn't know it, Susie Hunsecker's out there on the back step right now. He turns away, glancing towards Steve on the bandstand behind him.

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: He looks disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From D'Angelo's point of view.  CAMERA LOOKS UP at Steve. The Quintet is now reaching the end of the number, a driv rhythm of considerable excitement.  A waiter passes in f. and the CAMERA CRANES BACK through the curtained doorway the backstage part of the club.  This movement is continu as we see some other employees, including Jerry Wiggins, intermission pianist, who is waiting in the corridor near the fire-exit.  As he steps out of the door to discard a cigarette, CAMERA AGAIN CONTINUES ITS MOVEMENT, CRANING B AND DOWNWARD into the little courtyard.  Here, it discove the figure of a young woman who is waiting in the shadow near the steps of the fire-escape, listening to the music

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is SUSAN HUNSECKER.  She wears an expensive mink coa It is oddly in contrast with her personality; the face is sensitive and intelligent, but childlike and tragic.  A g in adolescence already burdened with problems beyond her capacity.  Over scene, the music continues.  Susan shifts her position, knowing that the session will soon be at an end and that the musicians will be coming backstage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is playing the last bars of the number; the whole group now in unison.

dialogues.speaker: QUINTET
dialogues.text: The music comes sharply, dramatically to its finish.  The is some applause.  The boys relax.  Steve reaches for the microphone and in the characteristically casual manner of the "cool" musician, announces the end of the set, thanki the audience, identifying the quintet by name and introdu the intermission pianist.  During this, Carson, Chico and Paul wander off the bandstand behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chico, Paul and Carson come through to the corridor backs As they do so, Chico, glancing out of the open door sees Susan in the courtyard.  He goes out onto the fire-escape Paul following behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi!  Susie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Chico.  Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Paul)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw a rope round this chick while I go get Steve. Chico goes swiftly back into the club.  Paul remains with Susan.  There is a momentary silence; Paul is embarrassed because Susan is.  Susan makes an effort at conversation, she nods towards the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full house...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packin' 'em in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve has been trapped by a young woman in spectacles, a much-too-earnest devotee of progressive jazz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly interested in jazz -- serious jazz.  You studied with Milhaud, didn't you?  This is such an interesting fusion of the traditional, classical form with the new progressive style, I just wanted to ask you how you came to form the group...-

dialogues.speaker: CHICO
dialogues.text: He comes through the curtains of the doorway, pausing as sees that Steve is involved with the Intellectual Young W

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve glancing at Chico over the shoulder of the Intellec Young Woman.  Seeing that Chico has something to say to h he wriggles out of the young woman's clutches by passing buck to the unfortunate to Fred Katz, who is descending f the bandstand behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we just sort of got together. (turning to introduce Fred)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if you ask Mr. Katz...He writes the stuff, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME CHICO
dialogues.text: Steve joins Chico and they go through the curtains into t corridor outside.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Chico, smiling, explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't waste your time there, man. You've got something better waiting outside... (as Steve looks at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie's out there.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: His reaction betrays some emotion. (Over scene the intermission pianist has begun to play a Blues number.) Steve moves a quick step towards the door to the courtyar then hesitates - almost as if he was afraid to go out.  H meets Chico's eye again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say...?

dialogues.speaker: CHICO
dialogues.text: He is amused, but sympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You proposed to her, not me. (slapping him on the back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get your answer...

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Susan, waiting at the foot of the iron steps, turns as St comes out on the fire escape above.  Steve comes quickly down the steps towards her, slowing down when he gets a f paces away from her.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She looks up at Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A CLOSE SHOT.  In his expression we read his mute inquiry

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SUSAN
dialogues.text: Quite deliberately, with her eyes moistened by love and affection...she nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great relief and happiness can be seen in the boy's face. After a moment, he moves to her and she to him.  They embrace swiftly, hold each other close and then kiss with passion.  Presently, when the kiss is over, Susan speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve...I'll...I'll try to make a good wife. Steve is still too choked with relief to speak.  For answ he clasps her more tightly to him.  The beam of light whi falls on the iron stairs behind them, narrows and then is extinguished...

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Paul has closed the door.  Turning, he shares a look with the grinning Chico and Fred Katz who has managed to escap from the young woman.  Before there is time for either of them to make a remark, Sidney comes through the curtains from the Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Fellows.  Where's the Chief? Sidney's manner is very friendly.  But it is immediately apparent from the reaction of the other three boys that n of them likes Sidney.  Fred is deliberately uncomprehendi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who gets the point)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dallas.  Is he around? Chico's back is to the closed door which opens onto the courtyard.  Chico nods in the opposite direction towards stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unhelpfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's around somewhere. Upstairs, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly, as he goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: Steve and Susan are still embracing.  Steve is exultantly proud and happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incoherent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is big, you know.  Very big! Let's go out later, drink some firewater.  With the boys.  Fred can call Millie and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, I'd rather you didn't say anything for a day or two...until I tell my brother...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: His sobering reaction shows this is something important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't told him yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling him in the morning after breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: Turning her head, she makes a little gesture, an unconsci movement, putting her fingers to her brow as if feeling a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He isn't going to like it. Susan says nothing.  She looks to Steve, smiling, but the smile is not too confident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want me to be with you...? Susan stoutly shakes her head.  Defensively she reassures Steve:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, my brother isn't as bad as he's painted.  He isn't perfect, but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he isn't going to like this, Susie.  And he makes you nervous, not me.  No, I take that back - he makes me nervous, too.  But I wouldn't give him a second thought if not for you. The topic evidently makes Susan uneasy.  In an effort to dismiss something that she does not want to think about, Susan puts her arms around Steve's neck again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's forget him and - But Steve is not so ready to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His stooge, Falco, is around - I saw him walk in. (soberly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been spying on me for weeks, Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly, perhaps too quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, I don't care - really I don't.  Sidney'd had a secret crush on me for years, but nothing we do is his business -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently insisting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he could be reporting back to your brother, couldn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, dear, please forget all of this.  What can it matter after tomorrow? Now Steve responds.  He grins, holds her closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a message for you; I love you. (kissing her lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I dedicate the next number to you?...And the next, and the next. Every Sunday I'll buy you a new bonnet -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused, but moved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the stores are open -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on Monday, I'll take it off and stroke your light brown hair and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on Tuesday - Hasenpfeffer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you think I realized I love you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made you write a beautiful song...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you had me eating that Chinese food!... They laugh and enjoyably; but then, as the CAMERA MOVES, realize that Sidney is there on the fire escape above the his manner is affable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can more than two enjoy this joke... (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Susie, I didn't expect to find you here. Steve says nothing.  But he obviously resents the intrusi and finds it difficult to conceal the fact.  Sidney comes down the fire escape towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's those glossy prints you promised?  Tonight's the latest I can place them -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely polite)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks, anyway - let's forget it. (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cold out here, Susie. Steve makes a move to lead Susan back inside.  It is a gesture which appears to dismiss Sidney.  Sidney chooses take umbrage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me apologize for getting you that press spread.  It's been an honor to serve you gratis. Steve turns to Sidney; his manner is quiet but challengin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (levelly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get the feeling, Falco, that you're always snooping around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly intervening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, stop it please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank D'Angelo has followed Sidney out onto the fire esca other members of the Quintet have also appeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you boys fighting about? Aggressively indignant, Sidney throws up his hands; he knocks on the metal of the fire escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill me!  Find me a door somewhere - I walked in without knocking! Sidney is trying to needle Steve; Steve's temper would normally have exploded; but now he controls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm feeling too good to fight with you, but that isn't what I said - I said you snoop.  For instance, what were you doing around my hotel the other night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (needling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begging your pardon, I haven't been down the bowery in years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soothingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on boys, break it up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overriding D'Angelo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next time you want information, Falco, don't scratch for it like a dog - ask for it like a man!

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: His face tightens; he appears to be mortally insulted and controlling himself with difficulty.  He turns his back swiftly on Steve, addressing Susan in a voice that has a sharp edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're going home, Susie, I'll drop you off... Sidney starts quickly up the fire escape.  This makes Ste angry and he steps forward to follow him.  But Chico contrives, without seeming to interfere to obstruct Steve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for the next set, Chief...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Chico.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Sidney comes inside.  When he is out of sight or the grou in the courtyard, his manner swiftly changes.  It's obvio now that his indignation was assumed; now he looks back towards the courtyard and there is shrewdness in his eyes he is assessing Steve's temper.  But, presently, seeing D'Angelo and the boys returning, he moves back to the curtains into the Club.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: As D'Angelo and the other boys go inside, Steve turns bac to Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fondly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so you don't leave me in a minor key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita has succeeded in recapturing Sidney near the entranc to the club.  Sidney, alert and interested, listens to he while keeping his eye on the bandstand in b.g. where the intermission pianist is finishing his performance and the quintet are returning, ready to mount the bandstand again

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you started a polka with Leo Bartha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That's what I mean - I'm being fired for what I didn't do. Sidney is amused.  Rita continues in a confidential manne which is heavily loaded with sex appeal and not-very- convincing air of injury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soto voce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He came in last week on a very dull rainy night.  I know who he was, but I didn't let on. (emphatically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't take his eyes off me all night.  Listening...? Rita has mistaken Sidney's shrewdly calculating expressio for inattention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avidly.  He was staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring.  Consequently, when he approached me on his way out I wasn't surprised, but I didn't let on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prompting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was writing a special Sunday piece on...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...cigarette girls... And naturally -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were thrilled to be interviewed. (she nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you "interviewed"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his apartment -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where was his wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know - it's a big apartment. But I wasn't interviewed.  In fact, I was totally unprepared for what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimacing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're old friends, Chickie - quit it!  A big columnist comes in this room, without his ball-and-chain and you make like a delicatessen counter!  What did you think would happen in his house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Sidney darling, the man must be out of his mind - it was only eleven o'clock in the morning! Despite himself, Sidney chuckles; but she is distressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment I was so taken aback that I said anything that popped into my sleepy head.  If I'm not mistaken, I even ordered the man out of his own house. Sidney's eyes have been caught by something at the other of the big room.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint.  Susan has come back into the cl with Steve and seems to be taking leave of him.  She star to walk through the club on her way out.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY AND RITA
dialogues.text: Sidney, with half his attention on Susan and Steve, liste to Rita's rueful protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rapidly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was furious and, by the time I could have put on a Tropical Island mood, I was out on the street!... (dolefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night Mr. Van Cleve calls me into his office here.  He's got nothing against me, he says but he can't afford to antagonize columnists.  I told him I still have Sonny at military academy, but Van Cleve's made of ice... Aware that Sidney is moving to leave her so that he can catch Susan, Rita detains him with an appeal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentative)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you could do something, Sidney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a quick nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm thinking, Rita. Maybe... Rita is anxious to cement the offer.  Delicately, she ask

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still keep your key under the mat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you be there by two-thirty? She drops her eyes, nods.  Sidney pats her arm and is gon She looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: Sidney overtakes Susan at the front entrance in time to o the door for her.  He has now reverted to another mood in which he appears to be sulking over the insult delivered him by Steve.  He goes out ahead of her.

dialogues.speaker: BANDSTAND
dialogues.text: The quintet are resuming their positions on the stand. Steve lingers a moment, his guitar already in his hand wh he talks to D'Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, I don't want any secrets from you.  I proposed to Susie tonight. D'Angelo hides his feelings, asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she accept?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like it, do you.  I think she will accept, but I'm not sure. She may be too dependent on her brother. He mounts the bandstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of good people in this town are dependent on her brother... Steve sits on the stool, quietly gives the beat to his gr and begins at once the guitar opening of a very simple an lonely melody. (The Sage.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While D'Angelo watches him, the boy continues.  CAMERA tracks slowly back through the club as the chatter and babble of the customers begins to diminish in appreciatio of the quiet melancholy of the music.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE ELYSIAN ROOM
dialogues.text: Susan is standing beside the poster which features Steve, listening to the music from inside the club.  Sidney come to join her.  He is now pretending to be hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're touchy, Sidney - don't be so touchy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruffly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't looking for a brawl.  I came to bring him a present. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna bite to eat? Susan shakes her head.  She looks up as she hears the doorman's whistle off screen.  Sidney moves forward to escort her to the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross the sidewalk and get into the cab.  It starts and CAMERA PANS with it.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE CAB
dialogues.text: Susan is relaxed, content but thoughtful.  Sidney flicks a quick, anxious look.  Finally, gloomily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feels like a Monday night, don't it...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to me.  Sometimes, the world feels like a cage.  Then someone comes along and opens the door...and it's never Monday night again... (turning to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you and Steve could like each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimacing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stick in each others craw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for one thing, he thinks J.J. is some kind of monster.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Quizzically, she studies Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He looks up sharply, (he is momentarily startled at Susan insight.) Swiftly, he assumes a protesting air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, your brother's one of my best friends, and -

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SUSAN
dialogues.text: She is not totally convinced by this performance.  She smiles skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  But someday I'd like to look into your clever mind and see what you REALLY think of him -

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: Sidney makes a show of indignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you come off to make a remark like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who could love a man who keeps jumping through burning hoops, like a trained poodle? Sidney doesn't immediately answer.  Susan drops her eyes, becoming absorbed in her own problems.  Cautiously, Sidne lets the momentary silence continue.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think J.J. likes Steve...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glibly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, yes, to my surprise.  He thinks he's very gifted - those boys'll go a big mile, he thinks. Susan says nothing.  Sidney, watching her closely, probes further:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel pretty strong about this boy? A pause.  Then Susan nods.  She is not looking at Sidney cannot see the watchfulness in his face.  Sidney prompts again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wedding bells, you mean? Again Susan nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants me to go on the road with them.  It's an eight month tour, all the way to Oregon...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: The news has considerable impact on him.  But he hides it saying lightly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations.  But don't go just for the ride!  Or didn't you accept the proposal?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SUSAN AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Susan continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to discuss it with J.J. in the morning. A pause.  Each is concerned with private thoughts.  Susan relaxed, adds quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's given me a big lift to know that some people want me for myself, not just because I'm my brother's sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chickie, I'll have to laugh at that - an attractive girl like you...! Susan ignores his remark, continuing thoughtfully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope that J.J. really likes Steve, that it isn't an act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an indignant edge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should he put on an act?  Your brother has told PRESIDENTS where to go and what to do! The taxi has pulled to a stop.  Susan sits for a moment before she remarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The act would be for my sake, not Steve's... Realizing that they have come to their destination, Susan gets up, moving out of CAMERA as she disembarks from the taxi.  CAMERA catches a glimpse of apprehension in Sidney eyes.  Quickly, he decides to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, getting out of the taxi, moves past CAMERA.  Sidne following her, instructs the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to cabbie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me.  I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney moves after the girl, calling: "Susie!"

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Hearing him, Susan turns back.  Sidney walks into shot to join her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my nature, Susie, but I'll talk to you like an uncle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't need an uncle, Sidney. They move through the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney quickly corrects himself, saying earnestly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean because I admire you - in fact, more than admire you - although that's neither here nor there. (quickly skipping to the important point)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, don't sell your brother short.  Talk this over with him, I mean - you'll find him a real friend.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Susan looks thoughtful, making no comment.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: Carefully (again probing) he prompts her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any message, in case I see J.J. later? Susan turns away and walks out past CAMERA.  Sidney watch her.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She looks back at Sidney, quietly firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Tell him for me that Steve Dallas is the first real man I've ever been in love with... She turns away and walks through the inner door, going do the corridor towards the elevators in background.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY
dialogues.text: The sincerity of the girl's manner strikes home to Sidney Now that her back is turned we see the sharp twinge of pa with which he hears the statement of her feelings for another man.  Angered, he wheels, striding out of the doo onto Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney returns to the cab, instructing the driver:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Twenty One Club. He climbs in and the taxi drives off down Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA HIGH, SHOOTING WEST down 52nd Street, as Sidney's pulls up, double parking in front of the 21 Club.  Sidney maneuvers his way between the parked cars towards the entrance and the CAMERA DESCENDS to SHOOT ALONG the court towards the entrance.  We see the figure of Jimmy Weldon his girl friend coming out of the Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Weldon is coming out of the Club accompanied by a girl; he is slightly tight.  As he steps through the oute doors, Weldon again spies Sidney on the sidewalk; he step to one side of the entrance way. Sidney slips through the congestion, but just as he tries enter the Club, Weldon's hand shoots out, neatly ambushin him, pulling him aside into the narrow courtyard.  Sidney instantly resentful of this manhandling, but has to adjus himself, assuming a quick smile for the benefit of Weldon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy!  This is a coincidence.  I am just going -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  A coincidence you should run into the very man you've been ducking all week! (to the girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my press agent, Joan. Weldon, jibing at Sidney, plays his remarks off the girl, who is amused; Sidney, of course, is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to reach you twice -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do for that hundred a week.  Fall out of bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy, I'm on my way inside right now to talk to Hunsecker.  I can promise you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horsing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joan, call a cop!  We'll arrest this kid for larceny! Sidney flinches, his pride touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, when your band was playing at Roseland -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was two months ago.  Take your hand out of my pocket, thief! The girl tries to quiet Weldon, who has gone from horsing loud contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Jimmy dear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  It's a dirty job, but I pay clean money for it, don't I? Abruptly Sidney bursts out, giving as good as he has take

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more you don't!  What is this - You're showing off for her?  They're supposed to hear you in Korea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smirking to the girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's intuitive - he knows he's getting fired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're funny, James, I'm a pretzel!  Drop dead! Weldon, shepherded by the girl, is already on his way acr the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nice knowing you, Sidney. Not cheap - but nice.  Happy unemployment insurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, entering the Club, threads his way through the crowded foyer, coming up to CAMERA near the foot of the staircase.  There he meets a Captain who turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you tonight, Mr. Falco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding towards the restaurant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is "he" inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But of course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone or surrounded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Senator, an Agent and Something - With - Long - Red - Hair. Sidney moves past CAMERA, coming a couple of paces toward the door to the restaurant.  He pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint.  Shooting through the doorway in the restaurant, we can see the group at the table. (Hunsecker's back is turned to us.) CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Sidney in foreground.  He decides not to go into restaurant and turns away out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney comes round the corner from the foyer and walks through the lounge to the door into the alcove where the phone booths are, CAMERA PANNING.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE BOOTHS
dialogues.text: Sidney moves briskly past the girl at the switchboard, instructing her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, get me Mr. Hunsecker. The girl reaches for a book of phone numbers, then rememb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right inside, Mr. Falco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from inside the booth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it isn't Long Distance. As the girl, shrugging, puts through the call, CAMERA mov closer to Sidney in the booth.  He hears the connection made, speaks at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J.?  It's me -- We are close enough to the instrument to hear the sound o voice on the other end.  Though the words are not distinguishable, it is quite clear that the speaker is no talking to the phone.  Sidney seems to relax, as if this something that happens often.  He waits, studying his manicured fingertips... Presently Sidney hears the voice on the other end become clearer.  It asks: "Yes?" CAMERA moves closer as Sidney s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., it's Sidney.  Can you come outside for one minute? Hunsecker's voice, filtered through the sound of the telephone, is sharp and tiny; but the words are now very clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come out?  No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tensely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk to you, alone, J.J., that's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had something to do for me - you didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You're dead, son - get yourself buried! There is a click as Hunsecker hangs up.  Sidney, more slowly, also hangs up.  Brooding, he comes out of the boo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney comes out of the door to the phone booths, walks through the lounge to the hallway.  He turns towards the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney comes to the door into the dining room, CAMERA tracking with him.  Here he pauses, looking towards...

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint.  Hunsecker is seated at a table which is cleverly his habitual position.  We see him only semi-back view, a broad and powerful back.  He is listeni to a man who has paused at his table, stooping over Hunse to whisper in his ear.  As the columnist listens, his han play with an omni-present pad and pencil which lie on the dinner table amongst an assortment of envelopes, mimeogra sheets and a telephone.  Beyond Hunsecker and the man talking to him are the SENATOR, the AGENT, and an attract if fatuous GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll check it in the morning, Low - thanks. The man leaves; Hunsecker is scribbling a note on the pad Meanwhile the Senator whispers something to the girl, who giggles softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney comes across to the table, nervous but deliberate. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Hunsecker in foreground. Sidney, without accosting him, stands a few feet from the columnist's elbow and deliberately lights a cigarette. Hunsecker, barely turning his head, sees him.  We have he of Hunsecker as a monster, but he is evidently in a mild phase of his metabolism, for he seems gentle, sad and qui as he turns his gaze casually to the Senator, totally ignoring the young man who stands behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, I often wish I were dead and wore a hearing aid...with a simple flick of a switch I could shut out the greedy murmur of little men...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A close shot.  Sidney shows no reaction to this insult. steps in closer, an Indian fixity in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., I need your ear for two minutes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting across Sidney, onto Hunsecker.  J.J. turns - but not to Sidney.  He raises his hand in a small gesture whi summons a passing Captain, who steps into picture at Sidn elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac!  I don't want this man at my table...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly but quietly interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a message from your sister. The Captain is already there.  But now Hunsecker's eyes h switched to Sidney's face.  For the briefest of moments, nothing happens.  Then Hunsecker, seeming to relax and ignoring the Captain whom he has summoned, turns back to casual conversation with the Senator as if nothing had happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Harvey.  We were interrupted before - In foreground, Sidney turns to the Captain with a carved smile, indicating that Hunsecker's change of topic is to interpreted as sanction for Sidney to remain.  The Captai not entirely convinced, retreats.  Sidney finds himself a chair, places it and takes a seat which is near enough to the table to establish his presence.  During this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who is mildly surprised and faintly embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Err...the Supreme Court story, I was telling you - Justice Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the Justice, that's right. But I think you had it in the column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothly, casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last July, the lead item... Sidney's interjection is quietly well-mannered.  Hunsecke totally ignores it.  The other members of the party are a little astonished at the interplay.  The girl, in particu is fascinated; she clearly admires Sidney's looks.  The Senator, noting this, glances at Sidney, accepting the po

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I believe that's precisely where I read it, too.  You see, J.J., where I get my reputation for being the best-informed man in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't kid a kidder.

dialogues.speaker: THE SENATOR, THE GIRL, AND THE AGENT
dialogues.text: The girl looks again towards Sidney.  The Senator again s this, addresses Sidney pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we caught your name, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Group shot.  The Senator in foreground, Sidney beyond Hunsecker in background, and the others on edge of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney Falco, sir.  And, of course, everyone knows and admires you, Senator Walker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (humorously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every four years I get less convinced of that.  This young lady is Miss Linda James. (indicates the Girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's managed by Manny Davis. (he indicates the Agent)

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Sidney nods pleasantly to the Girl and the Agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know Manny Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone knows Manny Davis... (as the phone rings on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...except MRS. Manny Davis. Hunsecker is picking up the phone, continuing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?  Go ahead, Billy - shoot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To intercut with the above.  The Senator, the Agent and t Girl watching Hunsecker.  The Agent's reaction to Hunseck remark is a sickly smile.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He repeats aloud a story which is told him over the telep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.  Sports cars in California are getting smaller and smaller...the other day you were crossing Hollywood Boulevard and you were hit by one...you had to go to the hospital and have it removed... (coolly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not following the column: I had it last week. During the speech, CAMERA eases back to include Sidney ag At the end, Sidney looks up in the direction of the Senat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in capital punishment, Senator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator, amused, asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney glances sidelong at Hunsecker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man has just been sentenced to death... Hunsecker's face hardens; aware of Sidney's impertinence, does not design to react directly; he turns towards the A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manny, what exactly are the UNSEEN gifts of this lovely young thing that you manage...?

dialogues.speaker: THE AGENT AND THE GIRL
dialogues.text: The Agent glances uneasily at the Girl beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she sings a little...you know, sings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by rote)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manny's faith in me is simply awe- inspiring, Mr. Hunsecker.  Actually, I'm still studying, but -

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He studies the Girl intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Singing, of course...straight concert and -

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Hunsecker's glance flicks between the Girl and the Senato

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why "of course"?  It might, for instance, be politics... As the Girl betrays herself with a nervous glance at the Senator beside her, CAMERA eases back to include him.  Th Senator is unruffled; gravely, he lights a cigar.  The Gi laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?  I mean "I"?  Are you kidding, Mr. Hunsecker?  With my Jersey City brains?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Again his glance links the Girl and the Senator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brains may be Jersey City, but the clothes are Trainor-Norell.

dialogues.speaker: THE SENATOR, THE AGENT AND THE GIRL
dialogues.text: The Girl and the Agent are both nervously uneasy.  The Senator closely examines the tip of his cigar and, with deliberation, turns towards Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you an actor, Mr. Falco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (supporting the change of subject)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I was thinking.  Are you, Mr. Falco?

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Hunsecker, for the first time, half-turns in Sidney's direction, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you guess it, Miss James?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME THE AGENT, THE GIRL AND THE SENATOR
dialogues.text: They all look at Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so pretty, that's how.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Sidney bitterly resents the adjective, but contrives to h the fact; he smiles, gracefully accepting the compliment. Hunsecker (who knows what Sidney feels) is pleased; he tu towards Sidney expansively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Falco, let it be said at once, is a man of FORTY faces, not one, none too pretty and ALL deceptive. See that grin?  It's the charming street urchin's face.  It's part of his "helpless" act - he throws himself on your mercy.  I skip the pleading nervous bit that sometimes blends over into bluster.  The moist grateful eye is a favorite face with him - it frequently ties in with the act of boyish candor: he's talking straight from the heart, get it?  He's got about half-a-dozen faces for the ladies, but the real cut one to me is the quick dependable chap - nothing he won't do for you in a pinch.  At least, so he says!  Tonight Mr. Falco, whom I did not invite to sit at this table, is about to show in his last and most pitiful role: pale face with tongue hanging out. In brief, gentlemen and Jersey Lilly, the boy sitting with us is a hungry press agent and fully up to all the tricks of his very slimy trade! Hunsecker has started his speech lightly, but it has buil up to enough cold contempt and feeling to embarrass and intimidate the others at the table.  In conclusion, Hunsecker, his eyes on Sidney, picks up a cigarette and waits expectantly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Match me, Sidney...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just this minute, J.J.... Amused, Hunsecker lights his own cigarette, turns towards man who comes up to the table.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: A single close up, to intercut with the above.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A matching single; Sidney's reaction to Hunsecker and to others at the table.

dialogues.speaker: THE AGENT, THE GIRL AND THE SENATOR
dialogues.text: To intercut with the above; their reactions of embarrassm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A florid MAN comes up to the table, obviously anxious to catch Hunsecker's attention.  Hunsecker, in the act of lighting, his own cigarette, scarcely looks at the man as dismisses him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know - that loafer of yours opens at the Latin Quarter next week. (more sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say goodbye, Lester! The florid man retreats.  To cover the embarrassment, the Senator makes a sally in Sidney's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask a naive question, Mr. Falco?  Exactly how does a press agent work...?

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Sidney doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you answer the man, Sidalee?  He's trying to take you off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Senator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just had a good example of it. A press agent eats a columnists dirt and is expected to call it manna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's manna?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Hunsecker glances spitefully at the Girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaven dust.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME THE AGENT, THE GIRL AND THE SENATOR
dialogues.text: The Senator continues to Sidney:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't you help columnists by furnishing them with items?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Sidney leans forward, indicating to the Senator some of t items of paper that litter the table in front of Hunsecke these are both handwritten notes and mimeograph sheets, scraps of assorted items from professional and amateur agents who supply the columnist.  Sidney fingers some of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, columnists can't get along without us.  Only our good and great friend, J.J., forgets to mention that.  We furnish him with items - Sidney lifts a mimeographed sheet, as an example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, some cheap, gruesome gags?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hunsecker now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You print them, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, with your clients' names attached.  That's the only reason those poor slobs pay you - to see their names in my column all over the world!  Now, as I make it out, you're doing ME a favor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that, J.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day that I can't get along without press agents' handouts, I'll close up shop, lock, stock and barrel and move to Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: THE AGENT, THE GIRL AND THE SENATOR
dialogues.text: The Agent makes the mistake of trying to agree with Hunse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweep out my igloo, here I come. CAMERA pulls back as Hunsecker leans forward across the table.  He vents upon the unfortunate Agent some of the annoyance prompted by Sidney's impertinence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Agent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Manny, you rode in here on the Senator's shirt tails, so shut your mouth! The Senator doesn't like this treatment of others and his manner and face show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, come, J.J., that's a little too harsh.  Anyone seems fair game for you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not as harsh, but -)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is not for you, Harvey, and you shouldn't be seen with him in public.  Because that's another part of a press agents life - he digs up scandal among prominent men and shovels it thin among the columnists who give him space.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR
dialogues.text: He finds Hunsecker's manner disturbing, but addresses him frontally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is some allusion here that escapes me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an edge of threat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're friends, Harvey - we go as far back as when you were a fresh kid Congressman, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does everything you say sound like a threat?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He leans back, speaking more quietly, enjoying himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's a mannerism - because I don't threaten friends, Harvey. But why furnish your enemies with ammunition?  You're a family man. Someday, with God willing, you may wanna be President.  Now here you are, Harvey, out in the open where any hep person knows that this one...

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Hunsecker leans into shot pointing directly at the Agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...is toting THAT one... Hunsecker points to the Girl and the CAMERA makes a sligh crab movement to include the Girl as Hunsecker points in turn to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...around for you... Another CAMERA movement.  Now Hunsecker is directly challenging the Senator.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He smiles disarmingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Are we kids or what?... Hunsecker rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hunsecker stands up, Sidney follows suit.  The Agent, very nervous, gets to his feet and the Girl does likewise The Senator, whose face is sober, also rises from the tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Senator, affably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time you come up, you might join me at my TV show. With Sidney making way for him, Hunsecker walks round the end of the table to the Senator.  The Senator faces Hunse solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly and cautiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, J.J., for what I consider sound advice. Hunsecker matches the Senator's solemnity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Thou, and sin no more. Hunsecker moves out of shot.  Sidney murmurs a "pleased t meet you" to the Senator; then he follows Hunsecker.  The Senator remains looking after Hunsecker.  Behind him, the Agent and the Girl, watch him apprehensively.  The Senato his face now showing the traces of guilt which he did not reveal to Hunsecker, seems unwilling to turn back to face them.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE WAY TO THE FOYER
dialogues.text: Hunsecker and Sidney.  Hunsecker addresses the Captain on his way out of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mac, don't let the Senator pay that check...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it, Mr. Hunsecker. CAMERA tracks with Hunsecker and Sidney as they move out towards the hat check stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President!  My big toe would make a better President! By now they are at the coatroom, Hunsecker smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hunsecker's coat, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find me a good one, Joe. He accepts the proferred coat as he moves past CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Doorman on the sidewalk has noticed Hunsecker, almost before the columnist has appeared.  The Doorman wheels, snapping his fingers and signaling towards the car park attendant, who can be seen at some distance in the backgr under the lights of the Kinney Car Park.  The attendant i seen to react with alacrity, running into the Park.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Putting on his overcoat, he addresses another of the Capt who has escorted him out of the Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan, anyone calls, tell 'em I'll be at the Morocco, maybe the Embers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Mr. Hunsecker. Sidney catches up with Hunsecker as he moves out onto the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your coat, Sidalee?  Saving tips? Sidney thinks of an impertinent reply, decides not to be drawn and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My curiosity is killing me; what are you so rambunctious about tonight? Sidney again does not answer; this time he points across street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's your fat friend.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: The car is framed in foreground; We can read the sign POL attached to the visor.  Two men in plain-clothes, detecti are in the front seats.  The man nearest is HARRY KELLO. Wanting to look like a prosperous business man, Kello loo soft, fat, mild and well-barbered; but he is dangerous; h knows it and enjoys it.  With "big shots" he is playful a kidding, always says just enough, not too much.  He is ve relaxed, and mild in manner, but underneath there is not only an animal energy, but a feral pressing at you.  His voice is on the hoarse side.  He measures situations automatically and instantly. The police radio is chattering.  Also in evidence is the telephone, the radio link with headquarters.  The detecti at the wheel nudges Kello, pointing across the street. Kello gets out of the car and moves to meet the columnist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he approaches)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonna sera, commendatore.  Come sta? Sidney follows a couple of paces behind Hunsecker; he is no hurry to meet the detective, whom he clearly dislikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Sidalee, that shows that Lt. Kello likes your people.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON KELLO
dialogues.text: Kello offers his hand to Hunsecker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my Brooklyn background, J.J. I'm good on Yiddish, too. Hunsecker accepting the handshake, winces with pretended pain at what is clearly an over-enthusiastic grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, am I supposed to say "uncle"? Kello laughs, releases the grip; Hunsecker strolls past h stoops to lean into the car listening to the police calls the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything fit to print, tonight? (to the policeman in the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Phil.  How're the kids. The detective inside the car answers, respectfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Mr. Hunsecker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any news fit to print tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joining Hunsecker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just checked "downtown".  Quiet everywhere tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incidentally, what happened to that doll? - You gave me the item last night.  Still alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  At Bellevue.  Still hanging on.  But they still don't know if she was pushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She mighta jumped.  Love suicide? (to the policeman in the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it for me, Phil...it's a real heart throb. While Phil lifts the radio phone, calling headquarters, Hunsecker turns back to Kello and Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mischievously, Hunsecker nods at Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kello)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hello to Sidney Falco.  Tickle him - he's been a bad boy tonight. He called you my fat friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mildly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. Instantly aware that J.J. is toying with Sidney, Kello offers his large hand to Sidney, who refuses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...I know you're the strongest cop in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call him the boy with the ice cream face!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, that's good - it's nice - in fact, it's APT, Harry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (modestly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got eyes.  I put things together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember ONCE when you didn't quite "put things together".  Boy! Was the Mayor mad! The memory of something unpleasant clouds Kello's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Citizens committees!  I didn't mean to hit the boy that hard.  Yeah, that's when a feller needed a friend and I won't forget his initials, J.J. The policeman in the car sticks his head out of the windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hunsecker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She died twenty minutes ago, Mr. Hunsecker.  They're still investigating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head with total dismissal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's show business.  Thanks, Phil. (to Kello)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you.

dialogues.speaker: 52ND STREET
dialogues.text: Kello gets into the police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he does so)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasta La Vista, J.J.  Hasta Luego.

dialogues.speaker: 52ND ST.
dialogues.text: The car moves off eastward.  Sidney and Hunsecker walk westward.  Sidney, falling into step with Hunsecker, glan back at the departing police car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spahish...that must show he likes "spigs", too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
