dialogues.text: I like Harry, but I can't deny he sweats a little. CAMERA now SHOOTS down 52nd Street.  Hunsecker, back to CAMERA, studies the evening, hearing the sound of a scree of female laughter from one of the groups in the distance A drunk is being thrown out of one of the strip tease joi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this dirty town. Amused, Hunsecker turns back; he signals across the stree to the car park, indicating that the big black Lincoln Continental should follow as he strolls with Sidney. HUNSECKER.  SIDNEY FOLLOWING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conjugate me a verb, Sidney.  For instance, TO PROMISE! CAMERA TRACKS with them in a CLOSE TWO SHOT.  Sidney is alert now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me you'd break up that romance - when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something done, J.J., but I doubt if you yourself know what's involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft and sardonic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a schoolboy - teach me, teach me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not break it up yourself?  You could do it in two minutes flat. Hunsecker pauses, halts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this late date you need explanations...?  Susie's all I got - now that she's growing up, I want my relationship with her to stay at least at par!  I don't intend to antagonize her if I don't have to. (starting to walk again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, be warned, son - I'll have to blitz you... Sidney follows quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, J.J., I don't think you got the cards to blitz me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't think so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to eye him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll listen one more minute. Sidney steps in front of Hunsecker, blocking his way for moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very rapidly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a year ago, you asked me to do a favor.  It was a thing - well, I never did a thing that dirty in all my life. Hunsecker, totally disinterested in Sidney's problems of conscience, signals to his car again, walks past Sidney, continues rapidly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, that brings us up to five weeks ago. "Sidney, I got a nasty little problem here." Did I say no? I'm frank to admit - it don't jell as fast as we like... But all of a sudden I CAN'T GET YOU ON THE PHONE NO MORE!  WHY?... And why, as of this date, am I frozen out of the column...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scornfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, lemme finish.  I DON'T LIKE THIS JOB!  That boy is dumb only on matinee days - otherwise he's got a head.  And Susan, like you said, she's growing up.  Two heads. What I mean, we got a slippery, dangerous problem here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incisively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not "we", Sidney, you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gamely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct me if I'm wrong - WE! Because when I'm out on this very slippery limb for you, you have to know what's involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha!  My right hand hasn't seen my left hand for thirty years! Sidney quickly moves into J.J.'s path, desperate to hold attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it, J.J. - don't get me wrong - in for a penny, in for a pound.  I'll see it through, but stop beating me around the head. Let me make a living!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his mouth tight and mean)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you promised - do it!  Don't finagle around.  It's later than you think. Hunsecker walks past Sidney, now making for the car at wh the attendant still waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Hunsecker passes him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse it, but it's later than you think.  That boy proposed tonight.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Hunsecker is HIT: he stops in his stride; he pauses and h turns slowly to look at Sidney.  Lowering, he hesitates, mind clicking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie told you that...?

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney, his eyes bright, nods.  Hunsecker studies Sidney, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder you've been so 'feisty' tonight. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you deliver? Sidney nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight.  Before you go to bed. The cat is in the bag and the bag is in the river.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Expressionless, he examines Sidney.  Then he walks off toward the car.  He tips the attendant, who thanks him, b instead of getting into the back of the car, he makes a small authoritative gesture to Nikko (double) to move ove so that Hunsecker himself may drive.  While Nikko does so Hunsecker turns back to Sidney, whom the CAMERA now inclu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a two time loser, Sidalee. The sentence could be severe...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He is satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Hunsecker gets into the driver's seat beside Nikko, the Japanese houseboy.  CAMERA is CLOSE on Hunsecker who does not look back but is clearly aware of the position of Sid as he puts the car into gear, revving the engine...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: The big car accelerates with impressive power.  In doing it sends a cloud of fumes and a swirl of dust in Sidney's direction.  He leaps out of the way, too late.  CAMERA MO closer to him as, with anger and ignominy he inspects his precious clothing for damage.  But, as he looks after the car, his face hardens into grim humor; he senses that thi petty gesture from Hunsecker is an indication of his vulnerability, not his strength.  As, dusting his coat, Sidney walks away, CAMERA RISES, watching his jaunty figu cross the street in the direction of 51st Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LONG SHOT looking over the round bar towards the entran Sidney comes in through the revolving doors and comes tow CAMERA.  His eyes search among the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE ANGLE.  A CAPTAIN approaches Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Sidney.  Wanna table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hopping tonight.  Leo Bartha been in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, having supper with the Mrs. She's over there. The Captain nods towards a booth on the other side of the bar where Mrs. Bartha is sitting alone.  Seeing that Bart is not with her, the Captain looks around the bar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's somewhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, I see him... Sidney is looking back towards the entrance hall, where..

dialogues.speaker: BARTHA
dialogues.text: Bartha comes forward (from the Men's Room) passing the Captain and Sidney.  Sidney moves to intercept him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Leo.  How goes that Sunday piece on cigarette girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOSE SHOT on Bartha as he turns towards Sidney, stoppi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you about it?

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney smiles at Bartha, but the threat is clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cigarettes girl...Rita.  And she took out all her hairpins, too.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME BARTHA
dialogues.text: He throws a quick glance at his wife in the booth in background.  CAMERA PULLS BACK as Sidney, who has noted t look, moves closer to Bartha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had the pleasure of meeting your wife.  You know what I wonder, Leo?  Could you use a hot little item for tomorrow's column? Sidney is pulling out of his pocket a pad on which to scribble the item.  But Bartha faces him squarely, speaki sotto voce but with emphasis:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, blackmail?  Beat it! Bartha turns on his heel and turns to walk towards his wi beyond.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney's face tightens.  After a pause, he makes a decisi and walks towards the booth.

dialogues.speaker: BARTHA AND HIS WIFE
dialogues.text: Bartha's wife is reading a tabloid and sipping champagne while her husband resumes eating a sandwich.  These two a antagonists in a long war.  Sidney comes up to the table, repeats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, I've never had the pleasure of meeting your wife... Bartha looks up.  What can he do?  Begrudgingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta...Sidney Falco...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chatty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. Falco.  If you know anything about horses, sit a minute.  Help yourself to a glass of this N.Y. State champagne - that's what my husband buys me. Mrs. Bartha pushes the champagne bottle in Sidney's direc as Sidney sits pleasantly; Bartha concentrates on his sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the imported wines aren't what they're cracked up to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose side are you on, Mr. Falco, his or mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, Mrs. Bartha, I'm a neutral observer for the United Nations.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bartha laughs, enjoying his deftness; then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your first name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney. Mrs. Bartha turns to concentrate on the names in the raci column of the tabloid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (searching the column)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No horse running tomorrow by that name...

dialogues.speaker: BARTHA, WIFE AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: An ANGLE favoring Bartha and Sidney.  Bartha glowers at h wife, resenting the fact that she has permitted Sidney to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to stop this nonsense, Loretta, these two dollar bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's compensation, Leo, for the marginal life we lead. (to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, did you hear the story about the cloak-and-suitor who -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right!  Tell him, so I can read it in Hunsecker's column first!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sidney, brightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, are you a spy for the other side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I actually sat down to give Leo an item. produces his pad again, begins to write on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, he wants to give you an item - don't be sullen. Bartha notes Sidney's writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you mind your own business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler! She returns to her paper, ignoring them, Sidney finishes scribbling the item.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just in case you'd like to print it, Leo.  It's a blind - no names mentioned.  But for your private information, the guy's name is Dallas. He pushes the item to Bartha, who reads it, briefly. Meanwhile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concentrating on the tabloid)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't a single name here that gives off vibrations... Bartha pushes the item back towards Sidney.  Sidney glanc quickly at Bartha's stony face then, significantly, turns towards his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything there with a name like "cigarette girl"? Bartha raises his head, looks squarely at Sidney with contempt and anger.  His wife is unaware of this reaction Still looking at the paper, she murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MMmmmm..."cigarette girl"... No, no horse with a name like that... Sidney pushes the item back towards Bartha.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bartha's attention is attracted by Sidney's gesture. She looks up, made aware of this strange by-play.

dialogues.speaker: BARTHA AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A CLOSE TWO SHOT.  Sidney waits; Bartha is white-lipped, pushes the item back again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't print blind items.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME WIFE
dialogues.text: She looks from Sidney to her husband and back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, chess or checkers...?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME BARTHA, MRS. BARTHA AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: The THREE SHOT favoring Bartha and Sidney.  Both Sidney a Bartha are now aware of Mrs. Bartha's curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither does Hunsecker. (fractional pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes to use the real names... A moment of chill silence.  Then Bartha gets to his feet, signals for a waiter.  As Sidney rises also:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we running?  What am I missing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiter, the check. (to wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is trying to hold a gun to my head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the horse!  Shotgun - Shotgun in the fifth! She quickly studies her newspaper again.  As quickly, Bar leans across the table and snatches it out of her hands. doing so, he upsets the glass of champagne, which contain only a few drops.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND BARTHA
dialogues.text: Bartha turns challengingly to Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to tell my wife, Sidney...?

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: She is brushing her lap with her napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to tell me that you poured champagne all over my lap.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME BARTHA AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Bartha ignores her, again challenges Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, tell her, I'm waiting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  Are you nuts or what? The Waiter arrives in picture beside them, puts the check the table and goes.  Bartha picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME WIFE
dialogues.text: Still mopping her dress with her napkin, she waits for he husband to speak.

dialogues.speaker: BARTHA
dialogues.text: He glances unhappily at his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorry, I can't let this man blackmail me...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BARTHA, BARTHA AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A THREE SHOT favoring Mrs. Bartha, her husband and Sidney foreground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blackmail...? Sidney decides to retreat.  He turns, starts to go.  But Bartha blocks his way, holding Sidney and explaining to t Wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants me to print a dirty smear item for keeping his mouth shut A momentarily pause.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME BARTHA
dialogues.text: He is uneasy, ashamed of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foolishly, Lorry, and I hope you'll understand... this cigarette girl...I was kidding around with her...this girl, I mean...I was kidding around and she took it seriously.  It was a case of bad judgment, Lorry, bad taste...and I'm just sorry, Lorry, that's all...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME WIFE
dialogues.text: She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME BARTHA, SIDNEY AND MRS. BARTHA
dialogues.text: The ANGLE favoring Bartha and Sidney, Mrs. Bartha in foreground.  Bartha now turns on Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend Hunsecker - you can tell him for me - he's a disgrace to his profession.  Never mind my bilious private life - I print a decent, responsible column - that's the way it stays!  Your man - there's nothing he won't print if it satisfies his vanity or his spite!  He'll use any spice to pepper up his daily garbage!  Tell him I said so and that, like yourself, he's got the morals of a guinea pig and the scruples of a gangster! Sidney tries to brazen it out, sneering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do now?  Whistle "The Stars and Stripes Forever?" Mrs. Bartha slides along the seat, reaching for her fur.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BARTHA
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK with her as she collects her belongings slides out between the tables and comes forward, passing Sidney to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you do now, Mr. Falco, is crow like a hen - you have just laid an egg. She presents her fur to her husband, and turns her back, inviting him to put it around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BARTHA AND WIFE
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE, favoring Bartha.  He has not fully underst the significance of his wife's gesture.  He studies her. She confirms his hopes as she adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, this is one of the cleanest things I've seen you do in years... With the fur around her shoulders, she turns and takes he husband's arm with some pride.  They walk away.  CAMERA ERASES BACK to include Sidney.  He is angry at himself - more for the failure of his efforts at blackmail than any sense of shame at the attempt.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS ELWELL
dialogues.text: A MEDIUM LONG SHOT.  At a booth on the other side of the sits a dapper gentleman with a twinkle of malice in his e He has been watching the altercation with keen interest a satisfaction.  Elwell gives some instructions to a waiter who is serving him with drinks, pointing towards Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney's face shows a burning resentment.  He glances abo him to see how much of the embarrassing scene has been observed.  As he moves away, the waiter walks into shot, addressing him.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: A waiter approaches Sidney.  He has a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis Elwell wants to see you, Sidney. The waiter nods towards the other side of the circular ba Sidney, his humiliation and rage still burning, looks off towards...

dialogues.speaker: OTIS ELWELL
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint.  Elwell beckons.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He comes round the circular bar.  He shows no eagerness t join Elwell, but approaches the table.  Elwell makes a gesture, inviting Sidney to sit.  Sidney doesn't accept i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see Bartha gave you cold tongue for supper. (as Sidney starts to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm late for a date with a dame. Then, returning, he leans over the table addressing Elwel with quiet anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis, if you're trying to blow this brawl into an item for your column - forget it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across Sidney and Elwell.  Elwell is quietly enjoying Sidney's display of hurt dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is dear old J.J. by the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his anger relapsing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call him up and ask - he might drop dead with shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were that easy, you wouldn't find an empty phone booth for the next two hours...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A CLOSE SHOT.  While Elwell continues, he is not looking Sidney.  Elwell's expression of dislike of Hunsecker is n overemphatic; but Sidney senses, nevertheless, that it is very real - and this gives him a new idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing over scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Talk of a wake! - they'd club each other to cater the affair for free!

dialogues.speaker: RESUME ELWELL AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Elwell looks up at Sidney as he continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, did I hear something about J.J. giving you the flit gun treatment - he shut you out of the column. (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney has rapidly resumed his manner of resentment (in order to exploit Elwell's dislike of Hunsecker).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that lunatic yet? Whims - egotistic whims!  Like the gag - when you got him for a friend, you don't need an enemy! (a pause, then:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what the fight with Bartha was about. "Leo", I says, "Hunsecker froze me out.  So I'm eating humble pie this month - please print me an item."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, instead, he printed his heel in your face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (morose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you're full of human feelings...

dialogues.speaker: ELWELL
dialogues.text: He has lost interest in Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a shrug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like most of the human race, Sidney, I'm bored.  I'd go a mile for a chuckle... Elwell's voice fades: his attention has been caught by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...three people are passing the table, squeezing their wa past; a man with two very fetching young women.  Elwell's eyes are riveted to the anatomy that is temptingly displa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (noting Elwell's preoccupation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and two miles for a pretty girl...?

dialogues.speaker: ELWELL
dialogues.text: He is unembarrassed at Sidney's all-too-accurate estimate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three...even four... Elwell turns back towards the papers on his table, a zipp document case and some publications among which a columni might search for scandal; among these is a magazine of semipornographic nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing, casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're really washed up with Hunsecker...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nature of Elwell's reading tastes is also not lost on Sidney.  With his eyes glancing at the magazine, Sidney n accepts the original offer to sit down.  He produces the slip of paper that Bartha rejected, offering it as illustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how much I'm washed with J.J.... As Elwell reads, Sidney continues giving a passing scruti apparently casual - to a picture of a girl on the magazin cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Otis, I make no brief for my bilious private life, but he's got the morals of a guinea pig and the scruples of a gangster. Elwell shows no undue enthusiasm for the item.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine, fat dirty item. (offering it back to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's it about? But Sidney doesn't take the paper back; he explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kid named Dallas, who runs a dinky jazz quintet. (he leans closer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps company with J.J.'s screwball sister...

dialogues.speaker: ELWELL
dialogues.text: This does get a reaction, a flicker of genuine interest. Elwell reads the item for a second time.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND ELWELL
dialogues.text: Watching Elwell read, Sidney encourages:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a real goody if, like me, you wanna clobber J.J.! Now Elwell lays the item down in front of him.  Clearly, is considering it.  Sidney prompts again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got his TV tomorrow.  He'd read it just before rehearsals. Elwell nods.  But he is still reluctant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm.  Trouble is I can't think of any good reason why I should print anything you give me.  I can't even think of a bad reason.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney drops his eyes to the magazine once more.  He fing it in a preoccupied but significant way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I introduce you to a lovely reason, Otis.  One that's good and bad...and available?

dialogues.speaker: ELWELL
dialogues.text: His eyes go from the magazine to Sidney; he gets the poin alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not an unreasonable man... Elwell reaches for the slip of paper once more.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND ELWELL
dialogues.text: In picking it up, Elwell clearly implies his readiness to accept the item - on conditions.  Sidney, in his turn, ge this point.  He turns towards the passing waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiter!  The check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita is in the bedroom.  She appears to have some familia to the premises... She hears the doorbell.  She makes swi adjustment to her appearance and takes a swift gulp of a drink as she carries it through to answer the door.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The outer room is lit only by one of the lamps on the des Rita crosses and goes to the door.  Sidney's shadow can b seen through the frosted glass.  At the door, Rita opens slowly and with a seductive manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! Sidney steps into the room.  Rita begins to close the doo prior to stepping into his embrace.  Sidney puts one arm about her.  But now she reacts to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis Elwell stands on the landing outside.  In most gentlemanly fashion, he takes off his hat.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This new arrival gets a dismal reaction from the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unembarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita, say hello to Otis Elwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with no welcome whatsoever)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elwell is not unaware of his cool reception.  He glances Sidney as he comes into the room.  But his manner is suav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends call me Otis - sometimes Tricky Otis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otis was outraged when I told him Van Cleve was going to fire you. Tell him not to pay any attention to anything you-know-who says about you-know-what. (to Otis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Otis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! Elwell sits down on the sette, stretches his limbs, smile at the girl.  Rita still says nothing.  Sidney mistakes h attitude for acquiescence.  He swallows his drink, sets i down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you two could talk the whole thing over till I got back. Rita looks at him sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those business meetings, honey - always coming up in the middle of the night. He grins at Rita.  She doesn't respond.  Turning, she goe swiftly through the door into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.  You can drop me off on your way... Emphasizing the asperity in her voice, she closes the doo behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elwell looks at Sidney; Sidney looks at Elwell.  Elwell g up slowly from the settee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused by acid)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consternation reigns... Sidney is uncomfortable, not sure how Elwell is taking th rejection.  Elwell glances at his wristwatch, lays down h drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Otis... Elwell shrugs, remarks pleasantly but with significance:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate J.J. -- but not that much at this moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a chance -- He goes into the bedroom, closing the door after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita is in a flurry of indignation.  Sitting on the bed, is fastening one high-heeled shoe.  Sidney stands glaring her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know who that man is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Otis Elwell.  The columnist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding with emphasis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's a perfect stranger to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explosively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So take five minutes!  Get acquainted!  He's an important man - he's lonely - don't be dumb! Rita, who one shoe on, has begun to search for the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want all of a sudden - Lady Godiva...?  Where's my other shoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of an act is this? Rita jumps to her feet.  Her righteous indignation is handicapped by the lop-sided stance caused by the lack of one shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I have any feelings? What am I?  A bowl of fruit?  A tangerine that peels in a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caustic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon!  I turn myself inside out to help you and now I'm a heavy. (stooping swiftly as he discovers her shoe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your shoe, there's your coat, that's the door! Contemptuously he thrusts the coat and the shoe into her arms.  The positive force of his manner gives the girl pa There is a silence.  Rita searches for words to explain t offense to her sensibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney...I...I don't do this sort of thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sort of thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as emphatic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you need him for a favor, don't you!  And so do I!  I need his column--tonight. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you ask me to do something about your job?  Don't you have a kid in Military School? A pause.  Sidney has struck brutally home.  Rita's lower trembles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a snake, Falco.  You're a louse, a real louse. Sidney's manner becomes swiftly sympathetic - but still urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (persuasively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey - he's going to help you! You want to lose your job? Rita begins to waver, her moral indignation losing ground before Sidney's reminders of her dire necessity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remonstrating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl needs a little romancing before she -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time I'll call in a guy to paint silver stars on the ceiling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a small voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you think of me if -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in to reassure her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing I didn't think of you before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly, with significance)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - that's what I mean! This attempt at humor signals to Sidney that he has broug her round.  He comes to her, pats her in an encouraging manner - to which she does not respond. He turns to the door, and picks up the glasses she has se down on the table behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he opens the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many snorts does it take to put you in that Tropical Island Mood? Sidney goes out.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Elwell overhears the last remark and as Sidney passes him he winks.  While Sidney pours another drink, Elwell faces the doorway.  Rita comes into it, stands on the threshold She is still far from enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an inspiration)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Havana!  That's where we met! Rita shakes her head morosely.  Sidney comes and puts a stiff drink into her hand.  Elwell raises the glass toast the girl, encouraging her to drink.  Rita responds dimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Otis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's mud in your column! Sidney laughs, more from relief than from the joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blessings on thee, the both...well... Gotta run now.  See you two kids later!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry back. At the door Sidney takes cheerful leave of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do anything I wouldn't do. That gives you lots of leeway.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY OUTSIDE SIDNEY'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Closing the door, Sidney seems pleased with himself.  He goes swiftly down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita remains on the threshold of the doorway between the rooms.  There is an uncomfortable silence.  Elwell carrie it off by coming to the girl, offering her a cigarette. accepts it.  Elwell studies her, smiling affectionately. Rita meets his eyes, avoids them again, then quietly offe the information:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palm Springs.  Two years ago. Elwell begins to laugh.  Whatever the memory, it seems to amuse him vastly because he continues to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right! Rita drinks.  She adds glumly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell Sidney. Elwell continues to laugh as we...

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE JUICE STAND
dialogues.text: Shooting east on 46th Street walks Sidney, coming out of entrance of his apartment, towards CAMERA.  He is pleased with himself, satisfied with his ingenuity in dealing wit Rita and Bartha. The streets behind him are dark and empty (it is about 3: in the morning).  CAMERA moves with Sidney as he steps briskly into the orange juice stand and lifts the receive from the pay telephone.  There are no other customers at counter, but the man behind is squeezing orange halves fo the day ahead, piling up a mountain of empties some of wh fall at Sidney's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA shoots up at the penthouse on the roof of the Bril Bldg.  The Budweiser sign is extinguished, a black silhou against the sky.  A light burns in the window of Hunsecke apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ringing of the telephone is heard in the big room - a impressively furnished apartment which has a decor indica that the owner thinks of himself in epic terms. CAMERA moves to discover Hunsecker in robe and pajamas, tapping at his typewriter.  Taking his leisurely time, he picks up the phone and eventually answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...?  You sound happy, Sidney. Why should you be happy when I'm not? (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see the papers when I get up. How do you spell Picasso, the French painter? (languidly writes down Picasso on his scratch pad, answering a query, dryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an item - I hear he goes out with three-eyed girls.

dialogues.speaker: ORANGE JUICE STAND
dialogues.text: CAMERA shoots past Sidney at the phone toward Broadway, which is now deserted.  A street-flushing truck goes by, moving through the dead city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be nice if you mentioned R-O-B-A-R-D - Robard's jazz joint -- it's his 20th anniversary.  Don't begrudge it to me, J.J. - I owe him lots of favors. (glancing toward the attendant to see that he has not overheard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you understand, don't you, that the Dallas skull is badly dented?  Oh, real bad... starting today, you can play marbles with his eyeballs. (even coquetting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hold out on me, J.J., mention Robard.  R.O. - (hangs up and walks to street)

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER'S PENTHOUSE
dialogues.text: Hunsecker is writing Robard's name on his pad, but he say into the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall see what we shall see... (lazily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't ever use this apartment phone again; I have a nervous sister. He cradles the phone, looks at it for a moment, switches eyes and then physically follows them, rising to stroll towards the glass doors onto the terrace.  He moves out a turns aside to look in at the adjoining window, which belongs to Susan's bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA shoots across Susan in foreground; she is asleep, tired, helpless, sweet kid.  The figure of her brother is seen - a dark shape on the terrace outside.  He moves awa across the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunsecker turns from the window.  CAMERA is close on his brooding face.  CAMERA tracks with him as he crosses towa the parapet.  At this height there is a wind which blows hair and the movement of the camera emphasizes a remarkab vista of the New York skyline.  The buildings are now dar only a few of the electric signs are left on all night. CAMERA comes to rest looking over Hunsecker's shoulder; i tilts downward to a view of Broadway below, Duffy Square the distance.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: A close-up; Hunsecker is looking down on his "kingdom". there is little love in the man's face, only authoritaria power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Hunsecker's viewpoint.  The streets empty, except fo an occasional passing taxi.  The street flushing truck co up Broadway from Duffy Square...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The identical camera set-up.  Through the dissolve the li changes from night to day; Broadway magically becomes a roaring stream of traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In foreground a NEWS VENDOR.  Sidney comes out of the exi of a subway, reaching for his pocket as he approaches the news vendor who offers him a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Globe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme The Record. Sidney buys and opens the paper.  CAMERA MOVES closer to shoot over his shoulder.  We see the gossip column which bears a photograph of Otis Elwell at the top.  Smirking w satisfaction, Sidney turns away from the CAMERA and throw the paper into a trash basket before he disappears into t impressive entrance of a large office building.  The sign above the doorway reads: THE NEW YORK GLOBE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Hunsecker's secretary, occupies a cubicle which is separated form the rest of the newsroom by a partition. From the big room beyond, comes the hum and chatter of a newspaper.  The walls of the urgent murmur of the staff o big newspaper.  The walls of Mary's cubicle are covered w photographs; filing cabinets are piled high with unopened mail; two wire service teletype machines click desultoril Mary is plain but attractive, past 30, a level-headed wom with a sense of integrity.  She is on the phone just now, bored with the insistent voice on the other end.  Beside an earnest young LAWYER waits with several papers in hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no power to retract, Mr. Cummings... I'm only Mr. Hunsecker's secretary.  No.  Nor can I agree that can retraction is necessary. Thank you for calling. Sidney has come through the newsroom in background.  He pauses tactfully, seeing Mary occupied with the lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (huffily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fail to see what's amusing about these papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get the boss to sign them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving her the papers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've said that six times - that's why I'm smiling. As the disgruntled lawyer leaves, Sidney comes in, wearin his most winning smile.  With a glance after the lawyer, making sure that he is not observed, Sidney greets Mary, assuming a brogue:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mary, me darlin' and phwat are ye up to today? Sidney's hand caresses her shoulder with a gesture which indicates a certain intimacy between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a question I usually like to ask YOU.  Your secretary phoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something about a Frank D'Angelo trying to reach you... Sidney reaches for the phone.  As he does so, Mary hesita and glances at a copy of The Record which lies on the des open at Otis Elwell's column.  She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the man who manages Susie's boyfriend? Sidney murmurs casually, "Yeah.  Why?" as he dials.  Mary holds up the paper, indicating the item.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen this?  In Otis Elwell's column. (reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The dreamy marijuana smoke of a lad who heads a highbrow jazz quintet is giving an inelegant odor to that elegant East Side Club where he works.  That's no way for a card-holding Party Member to act. Moscow won't like, you naughty boy!" Sidney accepts the paper from Mary, examines the item whi he talks to Sally on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally?  I got the message.  If D'Angelo calls again, tell him I'll be at the office around noon. He hangs up, continuing to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could this be that boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dallas?  Could be.  He doesn't look like a reefer smoker... He discards the paper with a show of disinterest.  Mary picks it up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at The Record again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is true, J.J.'s going to hit the ceiling... Sidney moves around behind Mary.  His eyes are fixed on a spike which sits on Mary's desk.  On it is impaled a proo of Hunsecker's column.  Meanwhile, he remarks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it be news to you that J.J.'s ceiling needs a plaster job every six weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint, Hunsecker's column.  The shot is just too distant for us to be able to read the print.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND MARY
dialogues.text: Sidney is looking at the column.  Mary is concentrated on papers before her.  Without looking up, she is clearly aw of Sidney's efforts to read the proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, you know that J.J. doesn't like people to look at the column proof in advance... Sidney, caught "in flagrante", laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, I'm not "people" - there's Falco blood, sweat and tears in that column. He turns away, changing the subject (apparently).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about dinner tonight? Mary turns to study him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bribing me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable under her scrutiny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why should I bribe the woman who holds most of my heart? Mary is thoughtful.  Without malice, in a detached sort o way, she examines Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a real rascal, Sidney.  I'd certainly dislike you if I didn't like you.  You're an amusing boy, but there isn't a drop of respect in you for anything alive - you're too immersed in the theology of making a fast buck.  Not that I don't sometimes feel that you yearn for something better... Sidney finds this analysis hard to take.  Again he tries laugh his way out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, don't try to sell me the Brooklyn Bridge.  I happen to know it belongs to the Dodgers. Mary, smiling, decides "to let him off the hook".  She ta the spike and the column and passes it across to Sidney's side of the desk, as she returns briskly to her business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind you looking at the proof of the column in advance, as long as J.J. doesn't know.  But don't do it like a boy stealing gum from a slot machine. Sidney doesn't like this; but, on the other hand, he does want to look at the column.  After only a momentary strug he picks the column off the spike and reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who put this item in about the comic? (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If there's a more hilarious funny man around than Herbie Temple at the Palace, you'll have to pardon us for not catching the name.  We were too busy screaming." Does this Temple have a press agent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It's one of J.J.'s occasional beau gestes.  Evidently the fellow's funny, so he gave him a plug. He goes to the door, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your favorite ribbon to go around your favorite chocolates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's wait till Christmas - it's more legitimate then. She looks after Sidney, thinks about him for a moment.  T she types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney comes down 47th Street from Broadway, making for t stage door entrance of the Palace theatre.  He walks confidently into the alleyway, paying no attention to the old doorman gossiping with the shoeshine boy at the chair next to the entrance.  The doorman turns, protesting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, without halting, looks back towards the Doorman, addressing him with the patronizing manner of a superior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herbit Temple here yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you can't come in now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in, Sonny Boy! He is already on his way into doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie will soon by finished and the comedian who open the stage show is ready and made-up in the wings.  He sit with his agent, (AL EVANS) a small, worried, bespectacled man, who waves an unlighted cigar as big as himself.  The converse in loud whispers, talking against the muffled an echoing sound of the film sound track, silhouetted agains the ghostly, distorted images on the big screen seen at a weird angle behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't waste words, Herbie, take my word.  I says, "look, Figo, I'm not selling you a dozen eggs, I'm selling you HERBIE TEMPLE", I says, so don't gimme your lip! The comedian, Herbie Temple, looks up.  Sidney comes thro a fire-proof door which separates the stage from the corridors to dressing room.  In background two chorus gir in costume are squeezed into a telephone booth.  Sidney joins the comedian and the agent; he smiles to the comedi while he addresses the agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Al! The agent looks from Sidney to Temple, surprised and displeased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when did you two get acquainted? Sidney has clearly never met Evans; blandly he chooses to regard the agent's remark as an introduction; he offers h hand with generous amiability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. Temple... The comic accepts the hand doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Sidney Falco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still dubious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, delighted... Evans stands up, warns the comic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch this guy, Herbie, he's a press agent. Temple's smile congeals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch him, Al, I s...s...stutter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in no way discouraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temple, I caught your act the other night and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you now?  On which bounce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and I just had to drop by and tell you how great I thought you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.  What time is it, Al?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got ten minutes. (to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you don't mind, Falco: we're busy and if - Sidney stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't mind.  I'm busy too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good!  We're all off to Utica, so excuse me, Mr. Frannis-on-the- Portisan. Sidney moves toward the doorway onto the corridor.  The chorus girls have now vacated the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But can I ask one impertinent question here?  With no criticism intended, because I know, Al, you earn your ten percent, how come you let a sock act like Herbie Temple tip-toe through town without a publicity build...? Smiling wise, Evans shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not buying it, Falco - no fish today. Sidney presses, as if annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not selling.  I'm just curious, that's all. Temple turns away from Sidney, leaving him to Evans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer the man, Al, if he asks you a question.  Quick, before he thinks up another! Evans moves to Sidney, trying to shepherd him out the way came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Temple doesn't believe in press agents - does that answer you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evans makes the mistake of laying a hand on Sidney's elbo Sidney doesn't like people touching him.  He reacts in anger, as we have seen before - fixes a burning eye on Ev

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your hand off, lump! (more politely, to Temple)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one believes in press agents, Temple, when they make claims they can't perform.  I got nothing to sell - I didn't come here to peddle - but if I tell a client that Hunsecker will give him space, it's not just talk! Sidney stops briskly up the stairs into the corridor. Evans, angry, is stalled for a moment of delay action by mention of the magic name of Hunsecker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after hesitation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you bull artist - !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him go, Al...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: But Sidney has already stepped to the phone booth and is dialing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Mary, let me speak to J.J., please...it's Sidney Falco...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting past Sidney in foreground onto Temple and Evans beyond, they watch him, open-mouthed.  Sidney notes their reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him it's important...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria is at her desk, bewildered as she speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Is this Sidney?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'll wait... While doing so, he glances back with disinterest at Evans and Temple.  The comedian and the agent exchange looks. Evans is uneasy; he comes up the steps into the corridor address Sidney with a deflated manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, nobody hired you!  We didn't talk any deal, and - With his hand over the mouthpiece, Sidney addresses Evans with contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, lump!  I told you I'm not selling fish... (abruptly reverting to the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J...Sidney!...How are you, sweetheart? (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... (then seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I know it's late, J.J., but is it too late to add something important to the column? (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not a relative, but important...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Shaking her head, Gloria places the phone down on the des looks at it as it chatters away.  She considers returning her typing, but, worried, picks the phone up again.  Sidn chattering voice is barely audible: "You know Herbie Temp the comic...?  What about him?  He's at the Palace and he great.  That's what about him.  And you'd do me a big bun basket of a favor if you would say it in tomorrow's colum

dialogues.speaker: RESUME BACKSTAGE PALACE THEATRE
dialogues.text: Temple and Evans are now staring at Sidney with considera respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The comedian and the agent in foreground, Sidney still on the phone beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you got a pencil there I'll suggest a word or two. Uh...uh... The comedian and the agent in foreground, Sidney still on the phone beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone, continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's a funnier man in the world than Herbie Temple at the Palace...uh...pardon us for not catching the name, we were too busy laughing.  No, make that 'screaming'. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sweet of you, J.J., thanks. Probably see you at Twenty One tonight.  No, for supper, late. Right. 'Bye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak to this lad, Al, ... to Mr. Falco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See me in my office. He turns and walks away down the corridor.  As he vanishe Temple starts after him.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Sidney walks off in the direction of the exit -- (not so fast that he can't be overtaken).  Temple hurries into th corridor and comes after him.  Evans also follows, though not so eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. (turning back to encourage Evans)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak to him, Al. (to Sidney, apologetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al makes all my deals. Sidney permits himself to be detained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly, looking toward Evans)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like a guy that's quick with the hands. (to Temple)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temple, you've been three passes behind for twenty years.  This could start you off big - T.V. and anywhere. Evans, not as wholly convinced as the comedian, comes up join them.  Temple looks at the agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it would cost a pretty penny, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Evans)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell him, I stutter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrewdly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...Why don't we wait till tomorrow? Sidney, shrugging, makes a negligent exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait as long as you like - you know where my office is. They look after him.  Evans face is cold and suspecting, Temple's face contains fresh warmth.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS OUTSIDE SIDNEY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Sidney comes briskly up the stairs.  Outside his door he pauses, listens, hearing the murmur of voices inside.  Th he walks in casually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney steps in, closing the door.  He pretends surprise he sees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Steve and D'Angelo waiting for him.  Sidney comes into SHOT.  Sally remains at her desk while Steve and D'Angelo are silent, looking at Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perkily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is here, a wake? D'Angelo rises from the couch, crossing to Sidney to hand him a copy of the tabloid, The Record.  It is folded open Elwell's column.  As he passes it to Sidney, D'Angelo mar with his thumbnail an item near the bottom of the column. Sidney takes the paper and reads. (He reads a little too quickly.)  Then he hands it back to D'Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve notes Sidney's too-perfunctory reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read as you run, don't you? Sidney turns on Steve, coldly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a habit with me.  So now I'm briefed.  So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at D'Angelo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank thinks I shouldn't have come here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a quick correction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Steve.  I said namely you shouldn't go around wild, blaming people without justification.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watchfully, to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might have a faint idea of how this item originated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Sidney.  He pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your idea of logic?  I tell the Judge I didn't murder the man - the Judge says, "Why not you?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only two men in this town could be responsible for that smear - you or Hunsecker or both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explosively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dallas, ask your own manager - he's standing here like a pained wolfhound - Hunsecker and Elwell are enemies to the knife.  So how do you get him doing J.J. a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a favor, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to you, yeah. (continuing rapidly and with heat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dallas, your mouth is as big as a basket and twice as empty!  I don't like you, comma, but neither do I go along with this column saying you smoke marijuana and belong with the Reds.  Also, since we're talking repulsive, J.J. won't like this for two cents!  Don't give me that look, Dallas - J.J. believes in fair play.  And secondly, this could splatter his sister with rotten egg by implication - your her boyfriend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney's manner is a little too vigorous. (In adopting an aggressive tone, he is really trying to needle Steve.) Steve, though on the verge of losing his temper, is sharp enough to notice the point:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking very fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expostulating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you what - excuse me for breathing, will ya? (wheeling to Sally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like it?  He comes to my office and -

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: Sensing the danger, D'Angelo moves forward soothingly between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, this gets nobody nowhere - you're over excited, Steve and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't apologize for me, Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...excited with good reason, I wanted to say. (to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because this endangers the future of the whole quintet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I cry...? Steve, with a glare at both men, goes to the phone on Sally's desk.  He dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...People catch on quick to such an item.  Van Cleve already called me - he's firing the quintet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what are you doing here?  Go over there and fight!  If Van Cleve fires your boy, it gives a lie the ring of truth! In background Steve speaks quietly into the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to speak to Miss Hunsecker, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (replying to Sidney's question)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on our way there now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who has wheeled on Steve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you calling her for...?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Sidney's reaction to the mention of Susan's name gives St food for thought.  While he waits for Susan to be summone to the phone, he studies Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the boyfriend, remember?  I hope one day she'll be my wife... (into the phone, gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Steve, Susie.  Don't be alarmed, Susie, but I want you to look at Elwell's column in The Record...today...No, about me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is on the phone.  Listening to what Steve says, she frightened - almost too frightened; it is as if, in some curious sense, she had been expecting this blow.  It brin an echo of an earlier tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smear?...What...What kind of smear...?  Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is on the phone in foreground, the others watching In particular, Sally, who stands near Steve, is studying with obvious sympathy.  She looks slowly towards Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on our way to the Elysian Room to dicker with Van Cleve - he's fired us already.  I'll call you later, dear... 'Bye!... He hangs up quietly, looks at Sidney and walks towards th door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door closes behind Steve, Frank follows, more slow As D'Angelo reaches the door, he pauses with his hand on doorknob and turns back to study Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He feels uneasy under D'Angelo's scrutiny.  Sally, in background, is also watching Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to D'Angelo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at...?

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: He does not answer for a moment.  The unspoken accusation his look is very clear.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ugly world, Sidney... (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I told Steve what I really think, he'd tear your head off...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He brazens it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sneering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: D'Angelo shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm interested in his future. D'Angelo goes slowly out.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He hesitates before turning towards Sally (because he realizes that this exchange with D'Angelo must have confi Sally in her suspicions).

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Her face shows that Sidney is right.  Sally is deeply hur disillusioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney turns to her, challenging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... Resentfully, Sidney moves about the room.  Sensing the silent accusation against him, he is aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Sally, sometimes I get the impression you think you live in Star-Bright Park.  This is life, kid - get used to it! Sidney comes to the phone on her desk.  He dials.  Then h glances swiftly at Sally and, carrying the phone, walks i the bedroom, dragging the long cord behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the phone comes alive, Sidney pushes the bedroom doo shut.  The gesture is as casual as he can contrive to mak it.  Keeping his voice fairly low so that it cannot be he in the other room, he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikko, is Mr. Hunsecker there? This is Mr. Falco.  Well, have him call me as soon as he can.  It's important. He sets the phone down on the bedside table, looks at it thoughtfully before he goes back to the bedroom door, ope it and goes back into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney stands on the threshold, studying Sally.  His mann is now more sympathetic as he asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you send my folks in Philly the check...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Leaving the bedroom door open, Sidney comes up to her, watches her shrewdly, cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put a lotta trust in you, Chickie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low-voiced)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do, Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't judge a situation where you don't know what's involved... Sally is putting paper in the typewriter, trying to hold head up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not judging... Sidney comes closer to her.  He puts his hand on the nape her neck, carrassing her.  Under his touch, the girl is unhappy, and yet at the same time, responsive.  Sidney st has power over her but she is disturbed by feelings of sh Feeling her relaxed, Sidney bends and kisses her on the s of the throat with more than negligence, for something ab her always excites him; his aggression tune in with her submissiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pathetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear, Sidney, I can't help it - sometimes I wonder what I see in you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's no way to talk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or what you see in me, for that matter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay down town tonight.  Maybe we'll take in a show, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want me to - The phone in the bedroom rings.  Sidney, reacting sharply forgets his advances to Sally as he turns towards the bed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhilarated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?  Hunsecker's gotta phone ME! He goes into the bedroom, closing the door as he goes. Sally looks at the closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney has picked up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, J.J....I presume you saw the Elwell smear. (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no medals - not yet.  Oh, it's worse than that - Aunty Van Cleve is firing them...from the horse's mouth... They were just here - in a panic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunsecker wears a dressing gown as he sits at his breakfa table.  Behind him are the big glass windows to the terra overlooking the Manhattan skyline.  The papers are at Hunsecker's elbow; his manner is crisp and cold:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was just there? (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be the death of me.  Sidalee! Why?  Didn't you just tell me that they've already traced this smear to you?  All they have to do now is to put two and two together and I'm a chicken in a pot!

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Sidney smiles confidently, answers calmly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., peace on earth, good will to men - it's working out just the way I planned.  Yeah, I guarantee this bomb will pop right on schedule, but you have to play your part - you be a Saint and let me be the Devil.  But I wanna talk to you first...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER'S PENTHOUSE
dialogues.text: Hunsecker pauses, eyes full of cold voltage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't come here.  Susie is up and about. (listening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He called her?  You'd better see me at the TV - three o'clock. He bangs down the phone, tense thought in his manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally is busy with her typing again, but in a depressed m when Sidney comes out of the bedroom to put the phone dow on her desk again.  He seems satisfied with himself, smug Sally watches him for a moment.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Sidney prepares to leave the apartment.  His tone is full confidence, self-assertive.  (For once Sidney is certain that he is smarter, more cunning than even Hunsecker).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the wise one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chickie, a lotta people think they're smart.  You watch.  They're dumb: they'll do the work for me! Just watch. Sidney makes for the door, goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan buys paper - DOLLY with her - toward elevator - she gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J. has not moved; he is thoughtful and morose.  Nikko, Japanese butler, comes in to remove the breakfast table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table can wait.  No calls.  I have to think about my TV show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to do.  I will come back later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you put the bread out on the terrace for the birds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but they don't come no more this time of year. Smiling, Nikko leaves.  Hunsecker picks up a pencil and makes a note on a pad, about birds no doubt.  Abruptly he looks up, calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie!  Come in a minute, dear... She has been trying to pass unnoticed to her room.  She comes forward to him; her manner is serious and wary.  Hi act is one of a tasteful Mammy singer, but he is watchful too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, you're very much in my thoughts today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a question, dear, with that newspaper in your hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Sidney tell you about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he phoned.  I don't know this boy too well.  Anything in these charges? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not being partial, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with quiet certainty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not.  I'm not! He soothes, smiles indulgent, but watchful:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, take it easy.  I'll trust your judgment - you don't have to protest with me. With a paternal gesture of affection, he holds out his ar inviting her into his comforting embrace.  Not wanting to she walks into his open waiting arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you trembling, dear...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History repeats itself.  Everything that happened to Alan Leslie...began with a smear like this... Hunsecker considers this gravely, as if it was a new and troubling thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... She leaves his arms; he watches keenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incoherent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just as if I've seen a ghost today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that wasn't your fault, dear, what happened to Leslie.  I've told you that a million times... He goes to her gently; she appraises both him and her wrenched life with brooding, frightened eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then whose fault was it, J.J.?  It was someone's fault, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have called the boy exactly balanced...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stronger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan was not...unbalanced when I married him.  And he was not...'indifferent to women' no matter what they said!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not fighting with you, puss... She gets up and walks around in considerable agitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never would have killed himself if I hadn't gone through with the annulment.  Don't you see that made all the rumors seem true?  I should have stood up for him...not run out. She turns to Hunsecker, her manner firmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., I want you to get them back their job, Steve and the Quintet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("incredulously")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean they've been fired already, on the basis of this crude smear? He walks away with a wag of indignation,  but turns, aski

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, you're sure there isn't some fire where there's this much smoke? Susan shakes her head emphatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know Steve.  No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe you can tell me if he's as solid as you say, why does he rap me every chance he gets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (involuntarily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney is a liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said Sidney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defiantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said Sidney!... Staring, he pauses; then he deftly changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, dear, we're drifting apart, you and I, and I don't like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we were talking about Sidney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with rasp)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me finish, dear.  You had your say, now let me have mine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
