dialogues.text: I haven't said anything yet, J.J., but if - Susan hesitates.  Hunsecker waits for her to continue.  B she isn't yet sure enough of herself or of the point she means to make.  She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started to say we're drifting apart.  A year ago, in your wildest dreams, would you have walked by that door without taking up this situation with me?  Today I had to call you in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking up the situation with you now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, I want to help you--, there's nothing I won't do for you. You're all I've got in the whole, wide world. Hunsecker strides about, elaborately playing on a note of disillusion and pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what have I got?  Alimony to a pair of tramps?  They're of no concern to me.  It's you who count, but don't get me wrong - I don't intend to let you break your neck again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., you said you want to help me - prove it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get Steve back his job...please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He means that much to you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your "prestige" it only takes a minute - ten cents worth of American Tel and Tel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're picking up my lingo, hon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (levelly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read your column every day... He looks at her with pursed lips and, for a change, some real interest.  Her level, straightforward manner has pin him down completely; he shows a slow, charming grin, as h goes for a private phone book:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, I like this new attitude of yours.  You're growing up and I like it!  I don't like it when you're limp and dependent, when you're odd and wayward.  This gives you a chance for real survival in a very lousy world.  Because, don't forget, dear, you won't always have me with you, will you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't... He crosses to the white desk phone, delaying dialing for moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Dallas boy must be good for you.  Why not bring him around today, before the show?  This time I'll clean my glasses for a better look. Susan doesn't like this idea, is evasive:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I can reach him in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can if you want to, and I know you'll want to... (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, what's your beef against little Sidney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steadily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm certain, I'll let you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man couldn't ask for a squarer shake. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have Billy Van Cleve... (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever tell anyone, Susie, how I'm tied to your apron strings... (to phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy!  J.J.!  What's this about that boy?  What boy?  Where are we, lug, in a drawing room comedy? You're brain is warming up, sweetheart - yeah, Dallas!... (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't explain your point of view, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTS TOWARDS the entrance to the TV theatre.  A line of people are queuing for Hunsecker's TV Broadcast which is advertised by large posters beside the entrance. taxi drives up in foreground; Susan Hunsecker gets out.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney comes up Sixth Avenue towards the theatre.  As he reaches the corner of the building, he halts, having seen

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Susan is seen in the act of paying the driver.  As the ta pulls away, Susan walks CAMERA left.

dialogues.speaker: TV THEATRE
dialogues.text: Susan pauses, deciding not to enter the theatre; turning looks about her and waits on the sidewalk outside.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney decides that this is not the moment to approach Su He glances down the sidestreet then moves off in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: SIDESTREET
dialogues.text: Sidney moves down the sidestreet towards a stage entrance through which are emerging some TV technicians.  He slips inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunsecker is standing at a table, stop watch in hand, reading aloud from a script which he is rehearsing and timing.  Beside him sits Mary busy typing more of the material from Hunsecker's handwritten note.  Mary is calm but he is irritable, trying to concentrate despite the bustle around him. An old movie star, MILDRED TAM, sits waiting in one of th canvas-backed chairs supplied for the guests on the show. BURTON, a manager, also waits, deadpan, at Hunsecker's el Hunsecker clicks his stop watch as he reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I was reminded of it this morning, when I noticed that the birds had gone South.  We want the same kind of freedom for ourselves - that's what the man said! (he clicks the watch, pauses to underline the phrase, continues:)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man has the right to face his accusers!  That's the American Way! Who said?  The man said!  From..." He turns in exasperation to Burton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burton, don't stand around.  If I go over I'll cut some items off the tail... Burton departs.  Mary whips a second sheet out of the typewriter, hands it to Hunsecker.  As he accepts it, Hunsecker looks off towards the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: SHOOTING towards the auditorium, from Hunsecker's viewpoi Sidney mounts the steps onto the stage.  Seeing that the columnist is surrounded but knowing that J.J. wants to ta to him privately, Sidney loiters so that J.J. can join hi as soon as he chooses to.  CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Hunsecker.  Only momentarily distracted by private considerations connected with Sidney's arrival, Hunsecker returns to the business of timing the script.  He clicks watch again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "From Washington through to Jefferson, from Lincoln and F.D.R. right up to today - the Democratic Way of Life!  That's what the man said!  Nowadays it doesn't export to well... (then, concluding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know...and I know...that our best secret weapon is D-E-M-O- C-R-A-C-Y. (dropping to a modest tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's never forget it, ladies and gentlemen."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney lingers beside the old movie star who is listening rapt, to Hunsecker's words.  Sidney is less impressed wit J.J.'s eloquence.  At the conclusion, Mildred applauds lightly.  She stands up and moves towards J.J.  J.J. want to talk to Sidney but is frustrated by the old movie star

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's grand, just grand, J.J.! (then, anxiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is my makeup all right?  You know, despite the scads of movies I've made, I've never appeared on TV yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting her short)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Mildred.  Of course. You look fine. (swiftly summoning Mary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, help Miss Tam - anything she wants; she's our star today. Under the pretense of studying the typed script, J.J. wal away across the stage.  Sidney strolls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TRACKING SHOT.  Sidney comes up beside Hunsecker, falls into step beside him.  As they cross towards a water cool at the back of the stage, they talk in rapid undertone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got that boy coming over here. (a glance at Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who is smiling faintly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a pocket fulla firecrackers - good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (narrowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you loused this up but good. If I can trust my eyes, and I think I can, Susie knows all about your dirty work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't hurt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't hurt?  I had to get him back his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smugly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that, too. (closer, faster)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, J.J., we can wrap this up in one neat bundle, addressed to the dumps - to oblivion.  We're going great, but please play it my way. I cased this kid. Know his ins and outs...He's fulla juice and vinegar, just begging for some big shot like you to give him a squeeze.  Do little Sidney a favor: squeeze! - You know, J.J. - the porcupine bit - needles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's too late.  I got him back the job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's the point - he won't accept your favor!  The manager yes, but not the boy. A pause.  Hunsecker renumerates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's got her in a tizzy, I'll tell you that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, he steams her up - wants her to stand on her own two feet and all that jazz!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's feet is she on now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presumably yours... (a hasty addition)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's according to St. Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this boy got that Susie likes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Integrity - acute, like indigestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean - integrity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating as before)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pocket fulla firecrackers - looking for a match! (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a new wrinkle to tell the truth... I never thought I'd make a killing on some guy's "integrity". Hunsecker gives him certain slow begrudging admiration:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of beans, ain't you?  But you know that you'll stand or fall by what you're doing now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins; confidently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calculated risk.  Only we happen to know, J.J., that you like me.  I'm your star pupil -- I reflect back to you your own talent. Hunsecker permits himself a faint smile.  Burton is approaching with script in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't like to take a bite of you; you're a cookie full of arsenic. Sidney smirks.  He turns away and goes off towards the auditorium in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank D'Angelo pays a taxi out of which he and Steve have just emerged.  Frank turns towards the boy, resuming a conversation as they stroll across the sidewalk towards t entrance of the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (depressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still think he's responsible for the smear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I'm convinced, but you'll never prove it in a million years. (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, you'll do what you want, but it can't hurt; he offers you an olive branch - so today like olives!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you're right, but - Steve completes the sentence with a slow shake of the hea compromise is a gesture which he finds very difficult.

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: D'Angelo studies the boy with a paternal affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, sometimes it's better not to look at your own honesty; but to look the other man in the face. Not because you're my meal ticket - which you are - but because I like you and the boys, please take my advice: we - D'Angelo stops, halted by an expression which he sees in Steve's face.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He is looking through the glass doors of the TV Theatre, longer listening to D'Angelo's words; his face has harden in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Steve's viewpoint.  Sidney has come out of the curta entrance to the auditorium.  CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Steve in foreground.  With a movement that suggests his annoyance at discovering Sidney present, Steve jerks open the glass door and moves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is waiting in the foyer.  She is standing in a posi where she has not been able to see Steve until he enters; now she moves forward to greet him.  As soon as she is ne him, she speaks in a quiet, urgent manner:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in an undertone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, before we go in - I'd like to... But she, too, is halted as Steve lays a hand on her arm. Seeing his look over her shoulder, she turns...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He is already strolling forward to join them.  CAMERA PAN with him to include Susie, Steve and D'Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Susie - This is a real surprise -- not one but three. J.J.'s just finishing up his rehearsal.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Hunsecker comes forward to the front of the stage looking towards...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, SUSAN, D'ANGELO AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: In the group that comes down the aisle of the empty theat

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He studies them, then calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunsecker back to CAMERA in foreground; he begins to whis The Wedding March to the rhythm of Steve and Susan's walk

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He breaks the rhythm of his stride, his face rigid.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He descends to meet them; his manner is full of welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan nervously makes the introduction - Steve is nervous D'Angelo hangs behind warily; Sidney is in background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, you remember my brother... STEVE & HUNSECKER (together)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Steve shakes the hand that the smiling Hunsecker gives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, son, looks like you went out and bought yourself a packet of trouble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been very kind about it, Mr. Hunsecker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give Susie credit for that.  I took her word that there was nothing to the smear.  Matter of fact, I'll have my say about smears on the show today.  That's why I'd like YOUR personal assurance, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hunsecker, there's nothing to that smear.  You have my sincere word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding judicially)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll by that, son.  Now, you owe ME a favor. (pausing; to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be good to my kid sister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she's had a peck of trouble for a kid... Hunsecker flicks a look at Sidney.  No one else, warier b the minute, knows what to say.  Hunsecker purrs onward:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie likes to keep her girlish secrets.  But in her heart of hearts I imagine, Dallas, that she fancies you in an uncommon way. Now, what about YOU, son?  Not just tom-catting around...I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., Steve isn't... Hunsecker cuts her off with lazy good nature:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Susie.  He wouldn't be much of a man if he didn't understand my concern.  Would you, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing, quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serious as a deacon...I like it.  I like your style, son!  In a world of old rags and bones, I like it! For instance, take Sidney. Hunsecker crosses toward Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Sidney got anywhere near Susie I'd break a bat over Sidney's head! (smiling faintly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney lives so much in a moral twilight that, when I said you were coming here, he predicted disaster. You wouldn't take my favor -- you'd chew up the job, he said, and spit it right back in my face! (sniffing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any truth in that...?

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO, STEVE AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: Steve is thrown for a loss momentarily; Frank steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Hunsecker, and if I can amplify --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motionless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't amplify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve wantsa thank you for this favor.  He --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (provocatively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, you don't listen!  J.J. just told you to shut your mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's about time you shut yours?  Who are you to tell a man like Frank D'Angelo to shut up?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warningly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, that isn't important -- But Steve, on a heated rip, has turned to Hunsecker:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he have to be here in our hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, has he bothered you before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it news to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, lots of people tell me I'm a gifted man, but I still can't see around corners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tolerantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just exactly what are you so hot about? (waiting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I know it's a difficult thing to be an artist in this crudest of possible worlds, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuts!  I'm not here as an artist! I'm here as an average Joe, who happens to love your sister Susie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with ironic smirk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just be careful you don't knock her down, huh? Steve stops dead.  Then, strangely and dangerously, he pi up Hunsecker's smile.  On each man's face the smile broad and grows up into a chuckle from each; but the meanness still flickers around Hunsecker's mouth.  Steve is out of the net!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, son, you lost me on that last hill.  Just give us the punch line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No punch line.  Maybe I was just admiring your know-how---yours and Falco's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you keep coupling me with Falco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here, isn't he?  Do you think, sir, when he dies he'll go to the dog and cat heaven?

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Even Hunsecker smiles.  Sidney likes neither the ridicule the turn of events.  He moves quickly past CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY, STEVE, D'ANGELO AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: Sidney comes round the row of theatre seats to attack Ste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's forget cats and dogs and other pseudo-literary remarks--- I'll just lay it on the line!  What about that big rumpus in my office today?  You were there, Frank! Where, according to St. Dallas, J.J. was responsible for the Elwell smear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go wild, Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild?  Take a look at them and see who's wild... Playing along nicely, Hunsecker looks at Steve and Frank slowly removes his arm from Susan; he pauses before askin Dallas:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uneasily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve was excited...he didn't mean it exactly the way it's stated here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Steve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you mean it...?

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY SUSAN
dialogues.text: What he likes to---            J.J., I don't want to say- With a roar Hunsecker takes them both out of play; he sta up.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY, STEVE, D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: Hunsecker enters from behind CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of you keep quiet! (to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made more damage here in one minute than a plague of locusts! If you're tired, Susie, sit down--- this needs investigation! (to Steve, quieter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you mean it...? (waiting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's go!  Let's go!... Steve is cornered, the other completely out of play.  He pauses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't take kindly to you and Falco selling me ethics.  Who's the injured party here, you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with contempt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now you're in no position to ask questions!  And your snide remarks---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stronger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, I haven't handed over punishing privileges to you YET!  Put the whip down and I might respect what you're saying... Switching his leonine tail, Hunsecker looks broodingly at Susie.  Frank says one beseeching word, "Steve...", but n one hears him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, did you know about this accusation...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you leave, son, I'll answer your question---Susan Hunsecker is the injured party here! (balefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or will I be hearing next that I don't even have my sister's welfare at heart...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE AND SUSAN
dialogues.text: Steve hesitates defensively but can't resist a small smil he moves nearer to Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hunsecker, you've got more twists than a barrel of pretzels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unturning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear that, Susie... (to Steve)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I can't cope with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan in foreground, Steve, Hunsecker and Sidney beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too shrewd for me so I'll just be honest.  Susie and I love each other, if I'm not mistaken, and we want to get married. Hunsecker pauses; Sidney throws in a stage whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him credit---the boy's gall is gorgeous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we hear what Susie has to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's stout of you, Dallas, but Susie may not care to air her dismal views in public... Steve walks to Susie, trying to lift her with his hopes a air of gentle urging and support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie...?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She stares at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunsecker doesn't like the drift of things; his mouth tightens and he speaks to Susan with veiled warning:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, as always, is free to say anything she thinks.  Go on, dear, say exactly what's on your mind, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those "dears" sound like daggers. May I suggest that you stop DARING her to speak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I lift my eyebrows?  What is this?  What are you trying to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strongly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to get Susie to stand up to you.  But your manner is so threatening that she's afraid to speak!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, you raise your voice again and you'll be outa here on your golden pratt!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Suddenly Susan lets loose, with restrained nervous energy she is near to tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, if only for my sake, I want this stopped!  And the same goes for you, too, J.J.!

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He interjects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contritely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, I'm sorry if---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think ALL men are fools!... Restraining tears, she runs up the steps to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, HUNSECKER AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Steve looks after her.  Sidney watches intently.  Hunseck smile is frostily taunting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Dallas, a plague on both our houses... (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may have to call this game on account of darkness... Steve turns a blank-eyed stare at him.  Tension gone, a s mumbling fatigue has set in.  Hunsecker plays it light:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If looks could kill, I'm dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't care about you -- you're fantastic.  My whole interest, if it's not too late, is in Susie...and how to undo what you've done to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what have I done to her, besides not buy her a new fur coat lately?  Sidney, you were right -- the boy's a dilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Because I don't like the way you toy with human lives? - Your contempt and malice?  Because I won't be the accomplice of your sick ego - and the way it's crippled Susie...?  You think of yourself - you and your column - you see yourself as a national glory...but to me, and thousands of others like me, you and your slimy scandal, your phony patriotics - to me, Mr. Hunsecker, you are a national disgrace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blandly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, I don't fancy shooting mosquitoes with elephant guns.  So suppose you just shuffle along and call it a day... He turns and stares away, but Steve stops him with---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my day with Susie isn't over yet and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten'll get you fifty you're playing hookey from a padded cell!

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Hunsecker comes up the steps from the auditorium, Sidney following closely behind.  In background, beyond, Steve a D'Angelo are walking up the aisle to the exit.  CAMERA TRACKS CLOSE on Sidney and Hunsecker.  Hunsecker's face i rigid.  Sidney, close at his elbow, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it, J.J., you did it good... Sidney is full of confidence.  But Hunsecker barely hears him (Hunsecker has been hurt very deeply by the boy's attack; in particular, by the appalling fear that what St has said is the kind of thing which Susan may also secret believe.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is still standing in the wings.  Mary is with her, obviously sympathetic.  The girl is drying her eyes with Kleenex, and Mary glances at her employer with a look of reproach.  Hunsecker walks round the table, obviously try to approach Susan; seeing this, Susan turns away and move further from him.  Hunsecker stops.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: There is some emotion in his face as he looks towards the girl.  More gently, he moves forward past CAMERA...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Sensing the approach of Hunsecker behind her, she moves a again; she is still crying, but is trying to recover. Presently Hunsecker approaches her again.  He speaks very gently, soothingly, comforting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in a mood, Susie, to run over to Milgrim's later and buy a few new frocks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a small voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm going home. Hunsecker again tries to come nearer to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want Sidney to drive you over? Ignoring the shake of her head, he calls to Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive Susie home.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Again we see some emotion in his face as he studies the g His eyes flick towards the stage behind him where Sidney stands watching.  He moves gently forward and then speaks a quiet voice which reveals how desperately he needs her reassurance:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie...I...I'd have to take it very much amiss if you ever saw that boy again.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: After a pause, she turns towards him; she looks him strai in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (levelly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never see him again.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He seems to take this as a gesture of forgiveness from he Now he touches her.  His need for her is apparent; he tri to reach her, tries to find an excuse to embrace her.  Sh submits to this very passively.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: A VERY CLOSE SHOT.  We see the effort with which she is controlling herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satisfied with this crumb of affection from his sister, Hunsecker lets her go.  Susan moves away, still avoiding eyes.  Then she goes off towards the steps down into the auditorium.  Sidney looks at Hunsecker, then after Susan follows her.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He goes back to Mary and the script.  He instructs her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Van Cleve.  Tell him he was right.  Tell him I said the Dallas boys are not worthy of his club. Poring over the typewritten pages, he senses Mary's eyes him.  He speaks to her quietly without raising his head a there is still an undertone of feeling in his voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary...for Susie's own good...don't give her misplaced sympathy... Mary says nothing.  Hunsecker gathers his papers and with visible effort to resume his public personality turns towards the machinery of the television broadcast in background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan crosses towards the doors out onto the street.  Sid comes behind her, watchful as he overtakes her near the doors.  He goes past her to open the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get you a cab... Susan stops dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from me. She goes out into the street.  Beyond, we see a crushing Hesitating, Sidney adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J. asked me to drive you over and - But Susan has already moved out of shot, hurrying across sidewalk to hail the taxi.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Uncertain what to do, whether to follow her or not, he mo after her.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She has already opened the door of the taxi.  She turns t see Sidney come up behind her.  As he enters SHOT, she repeats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to leave!  I don't know if Steve'll ever talk to me again and I'm ready to blame it all on you! She starts to get into the cab...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Alert, he moves to detain her (anxious to know exactly th extent of her suspicion.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sidney steps up, he grasps at the door of the taxi, trying to hold it open, but Susan pulls it shut, catching his fingers in the door.  Sidney steps back in pain...

dialogues.speaker: TAXI
dialogues.text: It drives off down Sixth Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Nursing the injury to his hand, he looks after the disappearing taxi.  As he recovers from the pain, his expression slowly changes to one of thoughtful appraisal. (Susan's suspicions maybe of less importance than some ot considerations.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunsecker and Sidney are washing in adjoining basins.  Co off, the former is in one of his punitive moods of silenc Sidney, despite his throbbing, bandaged finger, is feelin satisfied and self-confident.  He hums quietly.  Hunsecke throws him annoyed side-glances, but Sidney refuses to "catch on".  The following dialogue is spaced between the washing, the drying and hair-combing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's what "integrity" looks like.  Well, I'm always willing to learn... (later)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that slob, D'Angelo, your uncle? Sidney no longer hums; after a moment, he answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother's side--her brother. That reminds me, J.J., Susie looks run down.  She can stand a vacation and so can you.  People say, "Oh, the great J.J., he's made of iron!", but you can use a rest, guy. Sidney's cheerfulness annoys Hunsecker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you so chipper about?  If I put a cross on every one of your mistakes, you'd look like a graveyard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for anything I did today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, I know human nature.  Susie lied to me - she'll see that boy again. Hunsecker moves out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, J.J. - she won't give him up, but it doesn't matter. Because the real "money ball" is the boy, not Susan.  And if -- Hearing the sound of the door, Sidney turns sharply.  CAM MOVES to discover that Hunsecker has gone out.  Sidney, quickly, finishing the brushing of his hair, follows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two waiters are fussing over Hunsecker's table at which places are already set for Sidney and Hunsecker.  Matre d hands him an envelope as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hunsecker this was to be delivered to you personally - When the columnist comes up to the table, the waiters quickly pull out the table for him.  Sidney comes to join him; Sidney gets some attention, but considerably less. CAMERA MOVES CLOSER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These drinks are warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you like to have them on your table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you a critic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll change --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. (to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real money ball is the boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the boy...we're on the verge of a farce, a real farce.  As I see it, if Susie had stood behind him today he might have proved a threat. But since primarily he's wedded to his work, he's not going to be able to take it. A waiter shifts the position of the salad dish at Hunseck elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to waiter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop tinkering, pal - that horse radish won't jump a fence! The waiter retreats rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In brief, J.J., it's all over because any hour now the boy will give her up.  Is it a farce or not? Delicately salting his oysters, Hunsecker looks obliquely Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This syrup you're giving out, Sidney, you pour over waffles, not J.J. Hunsecker!  What do you mean that lousy kid will give up my sister? Hunsecker, with a casual gesture, tugs lightly at the end Sidney's tie. Hunsecker's gesture is playful, but it inflicts great inj to Sidney's dignity; Sidney cannot bear to be touched; he finds this liberty on J.J.'s part as intolerable as anyth he has experienced, and only with great difficulty contro himself.  The SHOT FAVORS Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Hunsecker continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does it matter who's sister? The main thing, they're through and -

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint.  Without turning, Hunsecker interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to forget how that boy talked to me today?

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Sidney senses a warning in Hunsecker's manner.  He protes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., is he worthy of a second glance from a man like you?  Is he, I mean?...

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint.  Pausing during the process of eating, Hunsecker reaches into an inside pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief epitaph: "The boy was talking when he should have been listening." (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bite on this. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Sidney as Hunsecker tosses i front of him an envelope.  Sidney opens it, extracts two steamship tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steamship tickets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he eats)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the next sailing of the Mary. Susan's run down - she's never been abroad and as you so cogently put it, I'm not made of iron. Sidney slowly pushes the envelope back to Hunsecker, who leaves it lying on the table before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.  Now that louse is outa Susie's hair for good.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He has an instinct to laugh; but something tells him not

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: As Sidney makes no response, Hunsecker slowly, carefully continues in a voice which is dangerously soft:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that boy taken apart.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: SHOOTING ACROSS Hunsecker onto Sidney.  Sidney puts down fork.  He sees now that the issue is serious and must be faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do something that would drive them right back into each other's arms?  Not to mention that this time Susie would know who shot the arrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjecting quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why give her real proof?  You nearly ruined her with her first husband - and you were right, J.J., - but she almost followed him out the window.  What do you want - a chronic invalid?

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: He wants no advice from Sidney.  He interrupts with quiet savagery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how to handle Susie.  You just handle the boy, Sidney... (scribbles on scratch pad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...preferably tonight. (pushes pad across to Sidney)

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY AND HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: SHOOTING ACROSS Hunsecker onto Sidney.  Sidney feels sick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, what's tomorrow - a holiday? CAMERA MOVES CLOSER as Sidney picks scratch pad up.  We c read two words: "Get Kello".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll go home - maybe I left my sense of humor in another suit.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Hunsecker finishes eating.  During the ensuing speech, wh he begins quietly and sensibly, Hunsecker's venomous feel are unexpectedly betrayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got that God-given brain - learn to use it!  Do you think it's a personal matter with me, this boy? Are you telling me I see things in terms of personal pique?  Don't you see that today that boy wiped his feet on the choice, on the predilections of sixty million men and women of the greatest country in the world!  If you had any morals yourself, you would understand the immorality of that boy's stand today!  It was not me he criticized - it was my readers!... CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Sidney.  Hunsecker manages t control himself; he reaches with nervous fingers toward h scribbling pad.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney's face has tightened.  He has begun now to realize the extent of this man's megalomania.  After a moment he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving, J.J....

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: SHOOTING ACROSS Sidney onto Hunsecker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a quiet warning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't remove the gangplank, Sidney; you may wanna get back on board.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney feels the chill of despair upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This crab gumbo - terrific!

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: SHOOTING ACROSS Hunsecker onto Sidney.  A waiter has come serve the next course.  Hunsecker appears relaxed, but Sidney is sightlessly staring at the piece of paper in hi hand.  He speaks with a quaver in his voice, for he has worked hard to make a life which is now ready to relinqui

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., it's one thing to wear your dog collar...but when it gets to be a noose...I'd rather have my freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man in jail is always for freedom. Sidney begins to get up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except, if you'll excuse me, I'm not in jail. Hunsecker looks up at Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you're in jail, Sidney. You're a prisoner of your own fears, of your own greed and ambition; you're in jail.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: From Hunsecker's viewpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J.  If you're trying to - He leans over Hunsecker and the CAMERA PULLS BACK to incl Hunsecker in f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, little boy, don't know who you are!  Talking around corners with the big shots, ten dollar dinners - fourteen suits and cashmere coats - you tell yourself THAT'S who you are!  Later you won't know who you are without a penthouse on upper Park!  But underneath it all, ratting around from day to day, you DO know who you are!  You're a fearful, ignorant nobody - a poor wop kid from the slums of Philly - hoping nobody else finds it out!

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A CLOSE UP.  He knows the truth of what is said.  But he takes refuge in quiet retaliation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little hunch occurs to me - you have just painted a self-portrait. You know who YOU are because you scare people - that's what you've got against this boy.  He -

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER
dialogues.text: Hunsecker is prepared to give it out, but not take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you what I want you to do tonight!

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He looks down on Hunsecker, leans over the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're blind, Mr. Magoo.  This is a crossroads for me.  I won't get Kello.  Not for a life-time pass to the Polo Grounds.  Not if you serve me Ingrid Bergman on a plate. CAMERA has PULLED BACK to include Hunsecker, whose attent has returned to his food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over patient)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney, I told you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J., I swear to you on my mother's life, I won't do it. (he leans even closer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you gave me your COLUMN I wouldn't do a thing like that... But as he speaks the last words, Sidney's voice falters because he has glanced down at the table...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: We see that an idea has entered his head - an idea that takes the wind out of his indignation.  His eyes lift rapidly to Hunsecker's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delicately touching the envelope)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who do you think writes the column while Susie and I are away for three months?...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He is quite speechless.  Over scene Hunsecker's voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The man in the moon?

dialogues.speaker: HUNSECKER AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTS across Sidney again onto Hunsecker.  Hunsec leans back, looks at Sidney. Seeing that Sidney has accepted the proposition, he smile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sidney. In a pleasantly affable way, he leans across the table to tap the hand with which Sidney is leaning on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, Sidney, I'll have that piece of paper back... Helplessly, Sidney unclenches a fist and reveals the slip paper which he had meant to keep.  Hunsecker takes it.  W his eyes on Sidney, he slowly tears it up...

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR STAND AND PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: D'Angelo is buying a cigar at the counter.  He turns as Steve opens the door of one of the booths and comes out. Steve is in a gloomy, irksome mood; D'Angelo is sympathet and fatherly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be down in a minute. CAMERA TRACKS with them as they come out into the hallway They move towards the side entrance, away from the elevat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does she wanna see you about? The boy shrugs impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't say. Some passersby come down the hall and enter a waiting elevator, barely glancing at D'Angelo and the boy.  D'Ang feels uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could think of better places to meet her, instead of here.  He lives on the whole top floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carelessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt that it matters any more.

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: He addresses Steve soberly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve.  You made a very dangerous enemy of him today.  Matter of fact, I'm very glad we got the tour ahead.  If I'm any judge, you hurt him today where he lives... He won't forget it and he won't forgive...

dialogues.speaker: RESUME STEVE AND D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: Steve is silent.  He hears the sound of the elevator door opening and turns. Susan comes out of the elevator, the one farthest from th and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she comes forward to join them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. D'Angelo. D'Angelo acknowledges her greeting, touches his hat and retires tactfully.  Susan faces Steve.  It's an awkward meeting.  Each does not know where the other stands.  She has thrown her fur coat about her shoulders like a cloak; will keep slipping off.  He is faintly embittered, a litt hurt and baffled, but he is sympathetic; he is involved a concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Steve.  I'm glad you could come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you buy me a cup of coffee? In there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan nods in the direction of the door into the little c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. As he walks with her towards the cafe:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on our way to Robard's for a benefit.  I've only got five minutes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they enter the cafe, the Counterman looks up from coun the day's take at the far end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late for service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just two cups of java.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a twinkle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We serve here only moka coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling faintly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it moke. The Counterman goes to the urn for the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN AND STEVE
dialogues.text: A closer angle.  They talk in quiet undertones.  Steve wa for her to speak first; she starts slowly, hesitantly, wi difficulty:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve...what you tried to do today...you tried to take me up on a high mountain...I couldn't go all the way...I failed you... (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you forgive me? (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I lost you, Steve?  Have I...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I was wrong, too... But there's no doubt, Susie, that we have to face some serious things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's ever stood up to my brother the way you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to the point)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you didn't do much about it, Susie.  You walked out, and there I was...solo...and not too good at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just didn't think that I could antagonize him, Steve -- for OUR sake, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, I was there for OUR sake, too.  But what a world it would be if we were all afraid to learn to walk and talk because it might offend poppa!  By the way, I think your brother was completely responsible for the smears...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: This accusation is made lightly, in passing.  But Susan reacts to it, trying to interject:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overriding her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't care about that now. He knew what he was doing today. He was laying down the conditions under which he MIGHT consent to our marriage - if I would bend to every whim of his, like Sidney!  I couldn't do that, Susie...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: After a pause, she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying goodbye, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN AND STEVE
dialogues.text: Steve flares up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  I'm saying that for your sake you have to make a clean break with your brother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrenched)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, please, Steve, please - one step at a time!  I was born only yesterday!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing, softer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told your brother I couldn't be his accomplice.  I can't be yours either, Susie, and encourage him to go on pulverizing you.  I know what type - he's my old man all over again! Susan, pathetically despairing, fingers the handle of her coffee cup, which she has not touched.  The coat slips fr her shoulders...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve stoops to pick it up, replaces it on her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This beautiful coat is more than just a coat... I hate it!  It's a mink straight-jacket! Susan turns to him.  She is deflated, lacking all will po

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drooping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, I feel exhausted...what do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not sure of himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not what you're doing now.  At least don't ask me - don't ask him. You're fighting for your life! What do YOU want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing, woodenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are saying goodbye, aren't you...?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He reacts vigorously, protesting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fish four days old...!  I can't buy it, Susie!  Right out of that mouth I love, like you're a ventriloquist's dummy, your BROTHER is saying goodbye!  Gee!...you want me to be honest, don't you?!

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: A despairing cry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Steve, I don't.  I don't.  Not if it KILLS me I don't!...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN AND STEVE
dialogues.text: It takes her a moment to recover.  When she does so, she gets up, leaving the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without luster)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not talk any more...you have to go... She moves towards the exit into the hallway; he follows.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: D'Angelo is waiting for them.  Silently they come up to j him, very depressed.  Susan looks towards D'Angelo, speak little pathetically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr. D'Angelo.  Take care of Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, Miss Hunsecker. He walks a little way down the corridor, again leaving th alone.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN AND STEVE
dialogues.text: She smiles at him, trying to smile, trying to make a joke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say something funny...Mr. Hasenfeffer. Steve steps to her quickly, kisses her.  Then he turns an swiftly walks off down the corridor without a backward glance.  He goes past D'Angelo, who walks quietly after h towards the exit in background.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She remains just in the attitude in which he left her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve comes out of the door, pauses without looking back. D'Angelo comes up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look back, Frank, see if she's still standing there... D'Angelo looks discreetly over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: From D'Angelo's point of view.  She is still standing whe Steve left her.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME STEVE AND D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: D'Angelo turns back to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still there... Steve, still without looking back, walks up the street; CAMERA TRACKING WITH THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sympathy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I don't like her - she's a very lovely person, but who can tell?  A year from now you might thank your stars that it turned out this way. (changing the subject)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, Robard said that... Steve, his manner full of pain, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, I don't want to make the benefit.  They'll be jammin' all night, and the way I feel -- I'd like to be alone -- I'd like just to walk and walk and never come back. D'Angelo takes him firmly by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I don't leave you alone on a night like this.  And, anyway, you promised... Steve looks at him, knowing that he can never shake off t devoted Frank; he shrugs.  They walk past CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heavy brass doors of the elevator slide open and the Elevator Man pulls open the grille.  Susan, still in the mood in which Steve left her, stands in the elevator for moment before she realizes that she has reached the top floor.  As she walks out, the Elevator Man looks at her anxiously.  CAMERA PANS with Susan towards the door to th apartment.  Susan fumbles for her key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment is dark as Susan enters.  She does not swit on the lights.  She walks through the shadows of the big room, which has a grim and menacing atmosphere.  She kick off her shoes and, hugging the coat about her for warmth walks to the glass windows of the terrace.  After a momen she opens them and steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan walks across the terrace.  At this height the wind very strong.  CAMERA TRACKS with the girl, emphasizing th dizzying panorama of New York at night.  The girl's manne is strange; she moves as if under compulsion, a sleepwalk When she reaches the stone parapet, she leans against it with her body slumped, still hugging the fur coat as if i were some protection against her misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vertically downward.  From Susan's point of view.  The st sidewalks of Broadway are a terrifying distance below.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: An angle, shooting sharply upwards against the night sky. Wind blows the girl's hair, as she looks fixedly downward Her face is blank, expressionless. (For a moment we may f for her, afraid that she may have suicide in mind.) But presently she lifts her head looking towards the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTS PAST the entrance to Robard's Club, framing the outline of the bridge in sky in background.  From ins comes the sound of music -- the Quintet. The taxi drives up; Sidney gets out; he glances at his wristwatch, looks around and then makes his way into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve Dallas' Quintet on the stand.  CAMERA FRAMES the gr in foreground, SHOOTING towards the entrance way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney has come in through the entrance.  He is taking of his overcoat.  He moves forward past the hat check room o the left, approaching the recess in which several music cases are stacked beside a coat rack on which the musicia overcoats are hung.

dialogues.speaker: DETAIL
dialogues.text: As he hangs up his coat, Sidney identifies the other coat black and white check raglan which he (and we) saw Steve wearing when he visited Hunsecker at the TV Studio.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A CLOSE SHOT.  The coat appears to have some significance for him; Sidney is under tension. A waiter, carrying a carton of beer cans, comes out of th doorway just behind Sidney, moving between him and the overcoat.  Thus interrupted, Sidney turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robard is standing at the bar, surrounded by a group of h cronies.  Drink is flowing and there is a sentimental moo of celebration. As Sidney arrives at the bar, ordering a drink, FRANK D'ANGELO is seen coming from the interior of the club whe Dallas and the Quintet can be seen playing; D'Angelo acco Robard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lew, Steve don't feel too good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjecting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA shoots past D'Angelo and Robard in f.g. towards Sidney, who overhears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So, if you don't mind, he'll leave after this set. In b.g., Sidney sets down his drink, reacting to this information.  Robard clamps D'Angelo on the shoulder, reassuring him with warm emphasis:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that boy, Frank.  Anything he does is okay with me...

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney, thinking rapidly, leaves the bar, moving unobtrusively but purposefully towards a telephone booth. He enters and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: A CLOSER ANGLE.  Shooting through the glass panel we see Sidney dialing.  His manner is urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long shot of the club exterior.  A different musical number is now being played in the interior. (GOODBYE BABY A black car comes swiftly under the bridge, turns into th little square opposite the club, braking sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car comes to a stop, CAMERA shoots across the hood onto the windshield where we see the insignia: POLICE. The occupants of the car are not visible.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ROBARD'S CLUB
dialogues.text: Sidney lingers near the doorway of the club.  He is looki across the square towards the car which can be seen in b. Now he turns and walks towards the coat rack, CAMERA trac with him.  He takes his own coat and, as he thrusts his a into the sleeve, contrives neatly to slip some unseen obj into the pocket of Steve's overcoat; CAMERA notes the gesture, but only very briefly.  Overscene a voice addres Sidney:

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: A CLOSE UP.  As he turns in swift apprehension, we note t moment of panic in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA shoots past Sidney in foreground towards D'Angelo advances on Sidney.  D'Angelo's manner is unfriendly; for instant we feel, like Sidney, that D'Angelo may have seen Sidney tampering with Steve's coat, but then we are reass as D'Angelo, deliberately using Sidney's surname, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Falco...I hate to give you this satisfaction - they broke it off tonight for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting across D'Angelo onto Sidney, who now relaxes, hi fears ungrounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that to Hunsecker - tell him we agree - he's a big man - he wins all the marbles!

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: As D'Angelo moves away again Sidney looks after him.  Onc more his face goes tense. (He asks himself, does this development - which he himself anticipated - change the situation?) He turns away, moving out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA moves with Sidney as he walks towards the doorway. There he hesitates again; he looks back into the club.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS
dialogues.text: From Sidney's viewpoint.  A LONG SHOT of Steve on the bandstand.  CAMERA PANS deliberately towards the coatrack f.g.  A group of newly arrived musicians walk into the sh setting down their instrument cases and starting to hang their coats. (Clearly, Sidney could not now return to the coat rack - even if he decided that he did want to undo h handiwork.)

dialogues.speaker: RESUME SIDNEY
dialogues.text: CAMERA, shooting out across the square, frames Sidney in Facing the inevitable, Sidney turns away, walks across th sidewalk.  On the other side of the square the headlamps the car blink twice.  Sidney walks towards it.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: A big man gets out of the seat next to the driver.  As he comes round the hood of the car, the headlamps of a passi truck illuminate him, identifying HARRY KELLO.  CAMERA PA as he walks to meet Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kello pauses as Sidney comes up to him, asks affably:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all the rush?  You said three o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing back towards club)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's leaving early.  After this "set".  He'll be out in a couple of minutes... They wait for a moment, listening to the sound of the mus in the distance.  It is a blues number (GOODBYE BABY) Kel hums nonchalantly; Sidney glances at him with irritation, finding something gruesome in his relaxed manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two plainclothes policemen inside, one at the wheel, the other in the back seat.  The latter leans forw to ask the former:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this deal tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the 2nd policeman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the lieutenant's "surprise parties", I think. Murph's tone shows obvious repugnance.  The 1st Policeman broods for a moment; he adds in a quiet, but viciously resentful manner:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of these days I'd like to turn in my badge and tangle with "POPSIE" myself - he's no good.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME KELLO AND SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Sidney, increasingly uncomfortable, turns to Kello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you wait up the block?  It's not going to look so good, right in front of the club... To Kello this is a great joke.  He laughs, enjoying Sidne uneasiness.  He begins to "cat and mouse" Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavily humorous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice, Sidney, that you give me this tip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjecting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - He's got them on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly nodding his approval)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And he's got them on him.  I appreciate a thing like that - I appreciate where you are looking out for the virtue of the city. Sidney, annoyed at this sarcasm, moves past Kello, not deigning to respond.  As he goes by, Kello grasps him forcibly by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your hurry, Snooks? CAMERA HAS PANNED to SHOOT towards the car out of which emerges a second detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (revolted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your hands off, Kello... Kello, holding Sidney, turns towards the second detective background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murph, how do you like this face? Why, I'll be darned -- it's melting! Something got you scared, Sidney...? Listen, rectify me a certain thing. Wasn't you kidding, Snooks, when you told J.J. I was fat...? Sidney jerks his arm away, rapidly retreats a few yards, safe distance from Kello.  CAMERA PANS with him to the bottom of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep in peace, Kello -- you're skinny -- but J.J. says you sweat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sidney in foreground, Kello and Murph beyond.  Kello laug but obviously he would like to be nearer to Sidney.  Perh to detain Sidney, Kello drawls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact?  He's a dilly, ain't he?  By the by, what did he have against this boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out with girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be darned.  And what does J.J. think he SHOULD do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impudently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go out with DIFFERENT girls!

dialogues.speaker: KELLO
dialogues.text: He moves forward a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get the peculiar impression, Snooks, that you don't like me. Could I be wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He turns swiftly and goes up the stairs out of Kello's re

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could be right, you fat slob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From half-way up the stairs.  Sidney comes up the steps t at a time.  Kello and Murphy are seen beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a guffaw)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back here, Sidney...I wanna chastise you!...

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: Sidney reaches the top.  He comes along the pedestrian wa up to CAMERA, slowing down he turns across the rail and looks down towards the square.  CAMERA MOVES to take in t scene in WIDE ANGLE: Sidney in foreground, the police car and detectives below, the entrance to Robard's across the square.  Sidney waits.  In the distance we can hear the music of Dallas' last number coming to an end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last bars of the number.  Enthusiastic applause.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He responds to the ovation, nicely but a little wearily. gets down off the stand.  There is too much noise to hear his parting words to his fellow musicians, but it is clea that he is urging them to stay without him.  He walks off towards the entrance to the club.

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: D'Angelo leaves the bar, in search of Steve.  He sees...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ROBARD'S CLUB
dialogues.text: Steve is putting his guitar away in the case, collecting overcoat.  In this gesture he is arrested by the sound of D'Angelo's voice over scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve! Steve, mildly startled, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting into the club.  D'Angelo comes forward from the He is a little drunk, a little emotional.  He waddles tow Steve, then takes the white carnation out of his buttonho and puts it in the buttonhole of Steve's coat, saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fondly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press this in your friendship book...Love is a crooked thing, friendship not... (then, sheepishly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, it comes out in the wash of a few drinks -- I'm a very sentimental guy.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME ROBARD'S CLUB
dialogues.text: Steve is touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it that way, Frank...don't change. He picks up his guitar case and makes for the door.  D'An goes a few paces with him, CAMERA TRACKING.  Then it move past D'Angelo, following Steve out onto the sidewalk, whe he stands under the light of the club framed against the dark background of the square.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS from the small figure of Steve to include Sid big in foreground.  Below him Kello and Murph turn toward the club.

dialogues.speaker: KELLO
dialogues.text: CLOSER ANGLE downward from Sidney's viewpoint.  Kello tur deliberately to look at the bridge above.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME BRIDGE
dialogues.text: Sidney sees Kello's look; he nods deliberately.  Below hi we see Kello and Murphy move swiftly to get into the car. Sidney, as if shrinking from a sight from which he doesn' wish to witness, draws back from the balustrade.  He turn and begins to walk towards CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: A LOW ANGLE SHOOTING upwards at the car, the stairs to th bridge in background.  As the doors of the car slam, it starts to move forward and, abruptly, its headlamps are switched on, glaring into the lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, concerned only with his only melancholy thoughts, walks down the sidewalk under the bridge.  The car headla illuminate him in their glare as they move across him. Steve, without undue, interest, glances back but continue on his way. CAMERA SHOOTS eastward towards the silhouette of the brid The Police Car turns as it comes out of the square under bridge towards CAMERA.  It moves slowly; again its headla flare into the lens.  CAMERA PULLING BACK includes Steve foreground.  Behind him the Police Car slows down at the curb; it barely stops as Kello slips out of the off-side door; then the car moves forward along the curb leaving h behind Steve.  As the car goes out of picture past CAMERA Kello strolls across the sidewalk, following Steve.  Stev looking past CAMERA, notices...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTS toward 2nd Avenue.  The Police Car slows do again at the curb and Murph gets out of it, turning to fa Steve.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME
dialogues.text: Steve, seeing the man ahead of him, notes something sligh menacing in his manner and slows down in his walk.  Then, instinctively, he realizes that there is a second man beh him, turns to look at Kello.  Kello approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, fella...! CAMERA MOVES CLOSER and CLOSER on Steve.  In his face we a growing sense of something wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JUMP CUT.  Loud noise, Chico Hamilton on the drums...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another jump cut in the sound track.  Silence.  It is an empty saloon, occupied only by a solitary drinker at one of the long bar, nursing a beer, and by the bartender who making out a dope sheet.  Sidney enters, strides to the b and throws down a jangling half dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of nickels, mister! While the change is made, Sidney stands with cocked head, listening in reality or imagination to what is happening down the street.  As the barman supplies the change, Sidn goes to the juke box and loads it with nickels saying ove his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A double Johnny Walker Black.  Or whatever you got.  Scotch. Sidney puts both hands on the juke box as if leaning on i With a click, drop and whirl, the music box comes to life music blares out.  Pausing a moment, Sidney turns back toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: He reaches for his drink, downs it.  He is shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once more, an abrupt sound transition: the jam session at full blast.  CAMERA FRAMES the musicians in foreground, b moves away from them towards the entrance in background. Near the doorway there is some activity; an attendant beckons to Robard who is drinking with D'Angelo.  Robard moves toward the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ROBARD'S CLUB
dialogues.text: CAMERA STARTS on D'Angelo at the bar.  He looks off after Robard.  There is little concern in his face, but as he watches, curiosity grows.  He strolls out after the proprietor.  CAMERA TRACKS with him as D'Angelo comes to join the little mob of two or three people on the sidewal PANNING, THE CAMERA now SHOOTS TOWARDS 2nd Avenue.  Beyon the bridge we can see the Police Car.  Kello and Murphy a beside one of the open doors (into which Steve has been carried). Murphy turns back, walks a few paces across the sidewalk and picks up Steve's music case, which he carrie back to the Squad Car.  He gets in and the car drives off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Robard, somebody just picked up one of your boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sa -- Wha --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'Angelo's face shows a bewildered astonishment and disma as he turns back to the couple of people who are talking Robard.  D'Angelo is a little befuddled with drink.  He pushes towards Robard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatsa matter, Lou?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to D'Angelo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to find out myself. They just picked up Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some fat guy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cop, a couple of cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smeared him all over the lot.

dialogues.speaker: D'ANGELO
dialogues.text: He turns to look back towards the direction in which the Police Car has departed.  He seems unable to comprehend w he has heard; but a slow and terrible fear is dawning on him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan opens the door to discover Frank D'Angelo in lobby. He speaks at once:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for your brother.  Is he home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (sensing the seriousness of his manner)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. D'Angelo - is something wrong? D'Angelo has no wish to become involved with the girl; he doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does he usually gets in, your night-owl brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seldom before five. (again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?  Would you care to come in a minute? D'Angelo backs away, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
